(Yang) tidak akan didatangi oleh kebatilan baik dari depan maupun dari belakang (pada masa lalu dan yang akan datang), yang diturunkan dari Tuhan Yang Mahabijaksana, Maha Terpuji. (Fushshilat/41: 42)

Demikianlah Allah menerangkan sifat-sifat Al-Qur'an dengan segala jaminan akan kesuciannya dari tangan-tangan manusia yang berusaha mengotorinya. Dia diturunkan kepada Nabi Muhammad saw yang diutus kepada umat manusia untuk memberikan kabar gembira tentang pahala dan surga bagi orang-orang yang beriman dan taat kepada ajaran agama, dan memberikan peringatan tentang azab dan neraka bagi yang kafir dan berbuat dosa.
text.106:
Dalam ayat ini Allah swt menerangkan bahwa Al-Qur'an diwahyu-kan kepada Nabi Muhammad saw secara berangsur-angsur sebagian demi sebagian, agar ia dapat membacakannya kepada umatnya, serta memberi pemahaman secara perlahan-lahan. Ayat Al-Qur'an pertama kali diwahyukan di bulan Ramadan, pada malam qadar, kemudian seterusnya diturunkan kepada Nabi berangsur-angsur sesuai dengan kebutuhan dan peristiwa yang terjadi dalam tempo kurang dari duapuluh tiga tahun. Dengan penurunan secara berangsur-angsur itu, umat Islam memperoleh keutamaan dan manfaat yang besar, antara lain:

Pertama: Kaum Muslimin mudah menghafalnya ketika diturunkan.

Kedua: Kaum Muslimin berkesempatan untuk memahami setiap kelompok ayat yang diturunkan, karena jangkauan maknanya yang luas memerlukan waktu yang cukup untuk memahaminya agar mendapat pemahaman yang tepat dan benar.

Ketiga: Kaum Muslimin tidak mengalami kegoncangan jiwa yang berarti dalam menghadapi berbagai perubahan yang dibawa oleh Islam. Sebelum kedatangan agama Islam, mereka menganut kepercayaan animis yang bermacam-macam, dan tidak memiliki peraturan dan tata kehidupan yang dipatuhi. Penurunan Al-Qur'an secara berangsur-angsur mempermudah mereka menyesuaikan diri dengan ajaran-ajaran yang baru, baik ajaran yang berhubungan dengan akidah, maupun yang berhubungan dengan ibadah dan kemasyarakatan.

Keempat: Sebagian ayat-ayat Al-Qur'an merupakan penjelasan yang berhubungan dengan suatu peristiwa yang terjadi.

Firman Allah swt:

Dan mereka (orang-orang kafir itu) tidak datang kepadamu (membawa) sesuatu yang aneh, melainkan Kami datangkan kepadamu yang benar dan penjelasan yang paling baik. (al-Furqan/25: 33)

Dengan demikian, kaum Muslimin merasakan bahwa mereka selalu mendapat bimbingan dan petunjuk dari Allah swt ketika menghadapi setiap peristiwa yang terjadi di antara mereka.

Bagi Nabi Muhammad saw, penurunan Al-Qur'an secara berangsur-angsur itu amat besar manfaatnya dalam memperteguh hatinya, seperti dijelaskan Allah dalam firman-Nya:

Dan orang-orang kafir berkata, "Mengapa Al-Qur'an itu tidak diturunkan kepadanya sekaligus?" Demikianlah, agar Kami memperteguh hatimu (Mu-hammad) dengannya dan Kami membacakannya secara tartil (berangsur-angsur, perlahan dan benar). (al-Furqan/25: 32)

Pada umumnya ayat-ayat yang diturunkan berkisar antara lima sampai dengan sepuluh ayat sesuai dengan kebutuhan, sebagaimana Umar bin Khaththab berkata:

Diriwayatkan dari Umar r.a., dia berkata, "Pelajarilah Al-Qur'an lima ayat lima ayat. Karena sesungguhnya Jibril menurunkannya lima ayat lima ayat. (Riwayat al-Baihaqi).
text.107:
Dalam ayat ini Allah swt memerintahkan kepada Rasul-Nya untuk menyatakan dengan tegas kepada kaum musyrikin yang ingkar kepada kebenaran Al-Qur'an itu, bahwa sekiranya mereka beriman maka keimanan mereka itu tidaklah memperkaya perbendaharaan rahmat-Nya. Demikian pula sebaliknya, sekiranya mereka tetap ingkar, tidak mau beriman kepada Al-Qur'an, keingkaran dan penolakan mereka itu tidaklah mengurangi keagungan Allah swt. Firman Allah:

Dan mereka berkata, "Kami tidak akan percaya kepadamu (Muhammad) sebelum engkau memancarkan mata air dari bumi untuk kami. (al-Isra'/17: 90)

Pernyataan Rasul saw ini merupakan celaan dan kecaman kepada kaum musyrikin, serta mengandung penghinaan kepada mereka. Bagaimanapun sikap mereka terhadap Al-Qur'an, tidak patut dipedulikan. Kebenaran Al-Qur'an tidak tergantung kepada sikap orang-orang yang ingkar itu. Tidak mengherankan kalau mereka menolak kebenaran Al-Qur'an, karena mereka memang orang Jahiliah. Tetapi orang-orang baik dan terpelajar di antara mereka tentu beriman dan tunduk sepenuhnya bila mendengar ayat-ayat Al-Qur'an dibacakan. Seperti Zaid bin Amru bin Nufail dan Waraqah bin Naufal yang telah membacakan kitab-kitab suci yang terdahulu sebelum Al-Qur'an diturunkan, dan mereka mengetahui kelak pada waktunya akan lahir seorang rasul akhir zaman. Mereka sujud dan bersyukur kepada Allah swt yang telah memenuhi janji-Nya, yaitu mengutus Muhammad saw sebagai rasul terakhir. Dengan turunnya ayat ini, Nabi Muhammad saw merasa terhibur hatinya, karena keimanan orang-orang yang terpelajar lebih berarti dari keimanan orang-orang jahil, meskipun keimanan orang-orang jahil itu tetap diharapkan.
text.108:
Dalam ayat ini Allah swt menerangkan bahwa orang-orang yang telah diberi ilmu itu mengucapkan tasbih, yaitu lafal Subhanallah (Mahasuci Allah), sewaktu sujud tanda syukur kepada Allah swt. Mereka menyucikan Tuhan dari sifat-sifat yang tidak patut bagi-Nya, seperti menyalahi janji-Nya kepada umat manusia untuk mengutus seorang rasul. Mereka juga mengatakan bahwa sebenarnya janji Allah itu telah datang dan menjadi kenyataan.

Ayat ini menunjukkan kebaikan membaca tasbih dalam sujud. 'Aisyah r.a. berkata, "Adalah Rasul saw banyak membaca dalam sujud dan rukuknya:

Mahasuci Engkau ya Allah Tuhan kami, kami bertasbih dengan memuji-Mu. Ya Allah ampunilah aku. (Riwayat Muslim dalam Sahihnya)
text.109:
Kemudian Allah swt menambahkan dalam ayat ini sifat-sifat yang terpuji pada orang-orang yang diberi ilmu itu. Mereka menelungkupkan muka, bersujud kepada Allah sambil menangis disebabkan bermacam-macam perasaan yang menghentak dada mereka, seperti perasaan takut kepada Allah, dan perasaan syukur atas kelahiran rasul yang dijanjikan. Pengaruh ajaran-ajaran Al-Qur'an meresap ke dalam jiwa mereka ketika mendengar ayat-ayat yang dibacakan, serta menambah kekhusyukan dan kerendahan hati mereka. Dengan demikian, mereka merasakan betapa kecilnya manusia di sisi Allah swt. Demikianlah sifat orang berilmu yang telah mencapai martabat yang mulia. Hatinya menjadi tunduk dan matanya mencucurkan air mata ketika Al-Qur'an dibacakan kepadanya. Mencucurkan air mata ketika mendengar atau membaca Al-Qur'an sangat terpuji dalam pandangan Islam.

Bersabda Rasulullah saw:

Bacalah Al-Qur'an dan menangislah, jika kamu tidak bisa menangis, maka usahakanlah sekuat-kuatnya agar dapat menangis.(Riwayat at-Tirmidzi dari Saad bin Abi Waqash)

Sabda Rasulullah saw lagi:

Dua mata yang tidak disentuh api neraka, yaitu yang menangis karena takut kepada Allah swt, dan mata yang berjaga-jaga di malam hari pada jalan Allah (jihad). (Riwayat at-Tirmidzi dari Ibnu 'Abbas)

Tidaklah masuk neraka seseorang yang menangis karena takut kepada Allah, kecuali bila air susu sapi dapat kembali ke dalam kantong susunya, dan tidaklah berkumpul pada seorang hamba, debu dalam peperangan di jalan Allah dengan asap api neraka. (Riwayat Muslim dan an-Nasa'i dari Abu Hurairah)
text.110:
Sabab nuzul ayat ini, menurut riwayat Ibnu Jarir ath-thabari dari Ibnu 'Abbas, bahwa Rasul saw pada suatu hari salat di Mekah, lalu beliau berdoa. Dalam doanya itu, beliau mengucapkan kata-kata, "Ya Allah Ya Rahman." Orang-orang musyrik yang mendengar ucapan Nabi itu berkata, "Perhatikanlah orang yang telah keluar dari agamanya ini, dilarangnya kita berdoa kepada dua Tuhan sedangkan dia sendiri berdoa kepada dua Tuhan. Maka turunlah ayat ini.

Menurut riwayat Adh-ahhak, sebab turun ayat ini ialah bahwa orang Yahudi bertanya kepada Rasul mengapa kata ar-Rahman sedikit beliau sebutkan, padahal di dalam Taurat, Allah banyak menyebutnya." Maka turunlah ayat ini.

Bilamana latar belakang turun ayat ini menurut riwayat yang pertama, maka Allah menjelaskan kepada kaum musyrikin bahwa kedua lafal itu (Allah dan ar-Rahman) walaupun berbeda namun sama-sama mengungkap-kan Zat Yang Maha Esa, Tuhan satu-satunya yang disembah. Pemahaman yang demikian sesuai dengan keterangan ayat 111.

Bila latar belakang turunnya ayat ini adalah riwayat yang kedua, maka Allah menjelaskan kepada orang Yahudi bahwa lafal itu sama-sama baik untuk mengutarakan apa yang dimaksud. Orang Yahudi memandang kata ar-Rahman lebih baik, karena sifat itu yang paling disukai Allah, sehingga banyak disebut dalam Taurat. Ar-Rahman banyak sekali disebut dalam Taurat karena Nabi Musa a.s. berwatak keras dan pemarah. Oleh karena itu, Allah banyak menyebutkan kata-kata ar- Rahman agar beliau bergaul dengan umatnya dengan kasih sayang, dan beliau sebagai seorang nabi tentulah mencontoh sifat-sifat Allah.

Pada ayat ini, Allah swt menjelaskan tentang keesaan Zat-Nya dengan nama-nama yang baik. Nama-nama yang baik itu hanyalah menggambarkan sifat-sifat kesempurnaan-Nya, bukan wujud Allah yang berdiri sendiri sebagai-mana anggapan kaum musyrikin.

Sesudah menyatakan kesamaan kedua kata itu, Allah menegaskan dalam ayat ini bahwa kedua lafal itu baik digunakan untuk berdoa, karena Tuhan mempunyai al-asma'ul husna (nama-nama yang paling baik). Tuhan memberikan keterangan dengan al-husna (paling baik) untuk nama-nama-Nya, karena mengandung pengertian yang mencakup segala sifat-sifat kesempurnaan, kemuliaan, dan keindahan yang tidak satu makhluk pun yang menyerupai.

Orang-orang Yahudi sesungguhnya tidaklah memungkiri nama-nama Allah yang baik itu. Hanya saja mereka memandang ar-Rahman nama yang terbaik di antara nama-nama Tuhan lainnya. Inilah yang tidak dibenarkan dalam ayat ini karena kedua nama tersebut termasuk al-asma'ul husna. Pendapat seperti di atas juga dianut oleh kaum Muslimin, dimana menurut mereka, ada nama yang lebih tinggi di antara al-asma'ul husna. Diriwayatkan bahwa Rasulullah saw mendengar seorang laki-laki membaca doa:

Ya Allah sesungguhnya aku memohon kepada-Mu, supaya aku benar-benar bersaksi bahwasanya Engkau Allah yang tiada tuhan melainkan Engkau, Yang Esa lagi tempat bergantung segala makhluk. Yang tiada beranak dan tiada dilahirkan dan tidak ada seorang pun yang setara dengan Dia. (Riwayat at-Tirmidzi dari Abdullah bin Buraidah al-Aslami dari ayahnya)

Setelah mendengar doa itu Nabi saw bersabda:

Demi Allah yang jiwaku di tangan-Nya, benar-benar laki-laki itu berdoa dengan nama Tuhan Yang Agung (al-asma' al-A'dham), yang bila Allah diseru dengan (menyebut) nama itu niscaya Dia menyempurnakannya, dan bila Allah diminta dengan (menyebut) nama itu niscaya Dia memberi. (Riwayat Ibnu Jarir ath-thabari dari Sa'ad)

Diriwayatkan pula oleh Muslim, Ahmad, at-Tirmidzi, dan Ibnu Abi Hatim dari Asma' binti Yazid bahwa Nabi saw bersabda:

Nama Allah Ta'ala Yang Maha Agung terletak pada dua ayat ini, yaitu:

Dan Tuhan kamu adalah Tuhan Yang Maha Esa, tidak ada tuhan selain Dia, Yang Maha Pengasih, Maha Penyayang. (al-Baqarah/2: 163)

Dan ayat yang kedua ialah pada pembukaan Surah ali 'Imran:

Alif Lam Mim. Allah, tidak ada tuhan selain Dia. Yang Mahahidup, Yang terus menerus-mengurus (makhluk-Nya). (ali 'Imran/3: 1-2)

Kemudian pada akhir ayat ini, Allah memerintahkan kepada Rasul agar di waktu salat jangan membaca ayat dengan suara keras dan jangan pula dengan suara yang rendah, tetapi di antara keduanya. Yang dimaksud dengan membaca ayat ini mencakup membaca basmalah dan ayat lainnya. Jika Rasul membaca dengan suara yang keras, tentu didengar oleh orang-orang musyrik dan mereka lalu mengejek, mengecam, dan mencaci-maki Al-Qur'an, Nabi, dan sahabat-sahabatnya. Namun jangan pula membaca dengan suara yang terlalu rendah sehingga para sahabat tidak dapat mendengarnya dengan jelas. Larangan ini turun ketika Rasul masih berada di Mekah berdasarkan riwayat Ibnu 'Abbas.

Menurut riwayat Ibnu 'Abbas, ketika Rasul berada di Mekah disuruh membaca ayat dengan suara yang tidak terlalu keras, tetapi juga tidak terlalu rendah, dilarang membaca dengan suara yang pelan dan rendah sehingga tidak terdengar. Tetapi sesudah hijrah ke Medinah, persoalan itu tidak dibahas lagi kecuali membaca ayat dalam salat dengan suara yang keras di luar batas tetap tidak dibenarkan.
text.111:
Pada ayat ini Nabi diajari cara memuji Allah swt yang memiliki sifat-sifat kemahaesaan, kesempurnaan, dan keagungan. Oleh karena itu, hanya Allah yang berhak menerima segala macam pujian-pujian dan rasa syukur dari hamba dan makhluk-Nya atas segala nikmat yang diberikan kepada mereka.

Ayat ini menjelaskan tiga sifat bagi Allah swt:

Pertama: Bahwa sesungguhnya Allah tidak memiliki anak, karena siapa yang memiliki anak tentu tidak menikmati segala nikmat yang dia miliki, tetapi sebagian nikmat itu dipersiapkan untuk anaknya yang ditinggalkannya bilamana dia sudah meninggal dunia. Mahasuci Allah swt dari sifat demikian. Orang yang punya anak terhalang untuk menikmati seluruh haknya dalam segala keadaan. Oleh sebab itu, manusia tidak patut menerima pujian dari segala makhluk. Dengan ayat ini, Allah swt menjelaskan dan membantah pandangan orang Yahudi yang mengatakan 'Uzair putra Tuhan, juga pendapat orang Nasrani yang mengatakan bahwa Al-Masih putra Tuhan, atau anggapan orang-orang musyrikin bahwa malaikat-malaikat adalah putri-putri Tuhan.

Kedua: Bahwa sesungguhnya Allah swt tidak mempunyai sekutu dalam kerajaan-Nya. Jika sekutu-Nya ada, tentu sulit untuk menentukan mana di antara keduanya yang berhak menerima pujian, rasa syukur, dan pengabdian para makhluk. Salah satu di antara dua tuhan tadi tentu memerlukan pertolongan dari yang lainnya dan akhirnya tidak ada satupun tuhan yang berdiri sendiri dan berdaulat secara mutlak di atas alam ini.

Ketiga: Bahwa sesungguhnya tak seorang pun di antara orang-orang yang hina diberi Allah kekuasaan yang akan melindunginya dari musuh yang mengancamnya.

Demikianlah Allah swt suci dari segala sifat-sifat yang mengurangi kesempurnaan-Nya, agar para hamba-Nya tidak ragu memanjatkan doa, syukur, dan pujian kepada-Nya. Kemudian Nabi saw diperintahkan untuk mengagungkan-Nya, baik dengan perkataan maupun dengan perbuatan. Mengagungkan dan mensucikan Allah itu adalah sebagai berikut:

Pertama: Mengagungkan Allah swt pada Zat-Nya dengan meyakini bahwa Allah itu wajib ada-Nya karena Zat-Nya sendiri tidak membutuhkan sesuatu yang lain. Dia tidak memerlukan sesuatu dari wujud ini.

Kedua: Mengagungkan Allah swt pada sifat-Nya, dengan meyakini bahwa hanya Dialah yang memiliki segala sifat-sifat kesempurnaan dan jauh dari sifat-sifat kekurangan.

Ketiga: Mengagungkan Allah swt pada af'al-Nya (perbuatan-Nya) dengan meyakini bahwa tidak ada suatu pun yang terjadi dalam alam ini, melainkan sesuai dengan hikmah dan kehendak-Nya.

Keempat: Mengagungkan Allah swt pada hukum-hukum-Nya, dengan meyakini bahwa hanya Dialah yang menjadi Penguasa yang ditaati di alam semesta ini, dimana perintah dan larangan bersumber darinya. Tidak ada seorang pun yang dapat membatasi dan membatalkan segala ketentuan-Nya atas sesuatu. Dialah yang memuliakan dan Dia pula yang menghinakan orang-orang yang Dia kehendaki.

Kelima: Mengagungkan nama-nama-Nya, yaitu menyeru dan menyebut Allah dengan nama-nama yang baik (al-asma'ul husna). Tidak menyifati Tuhan melainkan dengan sifat-sifat kesucian dan kesempurnaan.

en.name: The Night Journey
en.source: Aplikasi Quran Kementrian Agama Republik Indonesia

text.1:
Allah SWT declares His holiness with the word "subhana," so that humans acknowledge His sanctity from unworthy attributes and believe in His unparalleled attributes of greatness. This expression is also a declaration of His greatness, which enabled His servant to travel in one night, with a very rapid journey.

Allah SWT begins His word with subhana in this verse, and in several other verses, as a sign that the verse contains an extraordinary event that can only be accomplished through His will and power.

From the word asra', it can be understood that the Isra' of Prophet Muhammad SAW occurred at night, because the word asra in Arabic means traveling at night. The mention of lailan, in the form of isim nakirah, which means "night," is to describe that the Isra' event took place in a short night and also to reinforce the understanding that the Isra' event truly happened at night. Allah SWT isra'-ed His servant at night, because that is the most important time for servants to draw closer to Allah, and the best time to worship Him.

The word 'abdihi (His servant) in this verse refers to Prophet Muhammad SAW, who has been chosen as the last prophet. He received the order to make a night journey, as an honor to him.

This verse does not explain the exact time, either the time of departure or the time of Prophet Muhammad SAW's return to his residence in Mecca. It only explains that the Isra' of Prophet Muhammad SAW started from Masjidilharam, which is the famous mosque because the Kaaba (Baitullah) is located within it, to Masjidil Aqsa, which is located in Baitul Makdis. The mosque is called Masjidil Aqsa, which means "the farthest," because it is located far from the city of Mecca.

Furthermore, Allah SWT explains that Masjidil Aqsa and the surrounding areas are blessed by Allah because they are the place where revelations were sent down to the prophets. The land is fertile, making it a prosperous area. In addition, the mosque is among the mosques that became the place of worship for the prophets and their residence.

After that, Allah mentions the reason why Prophet Muhammad SAW was made to travel at night, which is to show the Prophet the signs of His greatness. These signs were witnessed by Muhammad SAW on his journey from Masjidilharam to Masjidil Aqsa, in the form of valuable experiences, steadfastness in facing various trials, and how vast the universe is and how Great Allah the Creator is. The new experiences witnessed by Prophet Muhammad were very useful in strengthening his heart to face various obstacles from his people, and to believe in the truth of Allah's revelations, both those that had been received and those that would be received.

At the end of this verse, Allah SWT explains that He is All-Hearing of the inner whispers of His servants and All-Seeing of all their actions. No heartbeat or body movement of all creatures in the heavens and the earth escapes His observation.

This verse mentions the occurrence of the Isra' event, which is the journey of Prophet Muhammad SAW from Masjidilharam to Masjidil Aqsa at night. Meanwhile, the Mi'raj event, which is the ascent of Prophet Muhammad from Masjidil Aqsa to Sidratul Muntaha (Mustawa), is not indicated by this verse, but is indicated in Surah an-Najm.

Almost all commentators of the Quran are of the opinion that the Isra' event occurred after Prophet Muhammad was sent as a messenger. The event occurred one year before the Hijrah. This is according to Imam az-Zuhri, Ibn Sa'ad, and others. Imam Nawawi also confirmed this. Even according to Ibn Hazm, the Isra' event occurred in the month of Rajab in the twelfth year after Muhammad's appointment as a prophet. Meanwhile, al-hafidh 'Abdul Gani al-Maqdisi chose the opinion that the Isra' and Mi'raj occurred on 27 Rajab, because that is when the community carries it out.

As for the hadiths that explain the occurrence of the Isra' are as follows:

First:

Anas bin Malik narrated that on the night when the Messenger of Allah SAW was taken from Masjidilharam, three people came to him before the revelation was sent down, while the Messenger was sleeping in Masjidilharam at that time. Then the first person said, "Who is this?" Then the second person replied, "He is the best of them (his people)." After that, the third person said, "Take the best one." On that night, the Prophet did not know who they were, until they came to the Prophet on another night while his eyes were sleeping but his heart was not sleeping. Such are the prophets, even though their eyes are closed, their hearts do not sleep. After that, the group did not speak to the Prophet at all until they took the Prophet and placed him around the Zamzam well. Among them was Jibril who controlled the Prophet, then Jibril split the part of the body, from the neck to the heart, so that his chest was empty. After that, Jibril washed the Prophet's heart with Zamzam water using his hand, so that his heart was cleansed. Then Jibril brought a vessel of gold filled with faith and wisdom. Then the contents of the vessel were poured to fill his chest and the veins of his throat and then it was closed again. (Riwayat al-Bukhari)

Second:

That the Prophet SAW said, "Suddenly someone (Jibril) came to me. Then he dissected and took out my heart. After that, a vessel made of gold full of faith was brought to me, then he washed my heart. After that, he poured the contents of the vessel into me. Then my heart was returned as before." (Riwayat al-Bukhari from Sa'sha'ah)

Third:

That the Messenger of Allah SAW said, "Buraq was brought to me, which is a white animal larger than a donkey, and smaller than a mule. It stepped its feet as far as the eye could see. Then I rode it, then it took me until I reached Baitul Makdis. Then I tied it to the place where the prophets tied their vehicles. Then I prayed two rak'ahs in it, then I went out. Then Jibril brought me a vessel containing liquor (khamar) and another containing milk; then I chose the one containing milk, then Jibril said, "You have chosen fitrah as the right choice." (Riwayat Ahmad from Anas bin Malik)

From these hadiths, it can be concluded that Prophet Muhammad was taken at night from Masjidilharam to Masjidil Aqsa with the permission of Allah under the guidance of the angel Jibril. Before Prophet Muhammad SAW was taken on that night, his heart was filled with faith and wisdom, so that he could withstand all kinds of trials and be steadfast in carrying out His commands. The journey was carried out by riding Buraq, which had extraordinary speed, so that Isra' and Mi'raj only took less than one night.

This verse does not explain in detail whether the Prophet SAW Isra' with his soul and body, or only his soul. That is why the commentators differ in opinion regarding this matter. The majority of them are of the opinion that the Isra' was carried out with the soul and body in a conscious state, not in a sleeping state. They put forward several reasons to strengthen their opinion, including:

a. The word subhana indicates a great event. If the Prophet was isra'-ed in a sleeping state, it would not be necessary to express it using a verse that is preceded by tasbih.

b. If the Isra' was carried out in a sleeping state, the Quraysh would not immediately deny it. The large number of Muslims who apostatized because of the Isra' event shows that the event was not an ordinary thing. The words of Ummu Hani who forbade the Prophet from telling anyone about the experiences he had during the Isra' so that they would not consider the Prophet SAW to be lying, also strengthens that the Isra' was carried out by the Prophet with his soul and body. This event caused Abu Bakar to be given the title as-shiddiq because he quickly and without hesitation justified the Prophet's Isra' with his soul and body, while other people found it difficult to accept.

c. Allah's word that uses bi'abdihi shows that the Prophet Isra' with his soul and body because the word a servant refers to the unity of body and soul.

The saying of Ibn 'Abbas that the Arabs use the word ru'ya in the sense of eyesight, then the word ru'ya mentioned in Allah's word below must be understood as seeing with the eyes.

And We did not make the vision which We showed you but as a trial for mankind. (al-Isra'/17: 60)

e. What was shown to the Prophet during Isra' and Mi'raj was eyesight that may occur because similar speed has been proven by humans with modern technology.

Some other commentators are of the opinion that the Isra' was carried out by the Prophet with his soul alone. They strengthen their opinion with the words of Mu'awiyah bin Abi Sufyan when asked about the Isra' of Prophet Muhammad SAW, he replied:

The Isra of the Prophet is a true dream that comes from Allah.

The opinion that says that the Isra' was only carried out with the soul is weak, because the sanad of the hadith that is used as hujjah or a guide is not clear.
text.2:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah has revealed the Torah to Moses (peace be upon him) as a guide for the Children of Israel. Allah SWT commanded Moses (peace be upon him) to say to his people, "Do not take besides Allah any protector who provides protection and resolves your affairs." The prohibition directed to his people was a prohibition that had also been conveyed by previous messengers through Allah's revelation. Contained within the above prohibition is a command for mankind to worship Allah alone and a prohibition against associating anything else with Him. There is also a prohibition against seeking help in all matters except from Him.

The giving of the Torah to Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) as a guide for his people is to provide understanding to the Muslims, that among the tasks of the messengers is to convey the religion of monotheism (tauhid), as was the task of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to them. It is also to remind them not to imitate the attitudes of previous communities, where after the departure of their messengers, they fabricated interpretations of Allah's words according to their desires, and wallowed in the valley of sin and manifest error.

That is why Allah SWT mentions repeatedly in the Qur'an the special qualities of Moses (peace be upon him) and the superiority of the Children of Israel over other nations that existed at that time. Allah also mentions the blessings bestowed upon them, with the intention that their consciences be awakened, then return to the right path, and live according to His guidance.
text.3:
Allah SWT also mentions their ancestors, those whom Allah saved together with Noah (peace be upon him) from the flood. They were saved by Allah through His revelation to Noah (peace be upon him). Noah was commanded to build an ark, so that he and his loyal people could avoid Allah's punishment that would be inflicted upon his people who denied his prophethood. This contains a warning for the Children of Israel to take an example and lesson from that event, and to follow the path taken by Prophet Noah. It also serves as a lesson for Muslims to maintain monotheism (tauhid) like Noah (peace be upon him) and his followers, and those who are grateful for Allah's blessings.

As an explanation of the aforementioned interpretation, it is necessary to present several hadith that explain that Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) was a prophet who was very grateful for Allah's blessings, as mentioned in the hadith:

First:

It is narrated by Muadh bin Anas Al-Juhaniy that the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "Indeed, Allah named Noah as a servant who is very grateful for Allah's blessings because when evening and morning came, he would say, 'Glory be to Allah when you are in the evening and in the morning, and to Him belongs all praise in the heavens and the earth when you are in the late afternoon and when you are at noon.'" (Narrated by Ibn Mardawaih)

Second:

Whenever Prophet Noah put on clothes and ate food, he would praise Allah SWT. Thus, he was named "a servant who is very grateful for Allah's blessings." (Narrated by Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari, al-Baihaqi, and al-Hakim from Salman al-Farisi).

Such are the prayers and glorifications (tasbih) uttered by Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) which are worthy of being emulated and practiced by Muslims.
text.4:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah revealed to Musa (peace be upon him), as stated in the Torah, that the Children of Israel would cause mischief twice in the land of Palestine, so Allah mobilized their enemies to kill, plunder, and destroy their land.

After repenting, Allah released them from this misery, their kingdom was restored, and they were granted wealth and power, both in terms of possessions and strength in terms of offspring and national defense.

However, they returned to causing mischief, so Allah Almighty mobilized their enemies again to destroy it. This is a punishment in this world, and in the Hereafter they will receive the torment of Hell.

Among their acts of disobedience were:

First, disregarding Allah's commands and changing the contents of the Torah.

Second, their abomination of killing Zakaria and Yahya, and their attempt to kill Nabi Isa (peace be upon him).

They committed these acts of disobedience by boasting and displaying arrogance. This shows that the evils they committed had exceeded the limits of humanity.

Allah then explained the consequences that would befall them because of the first act of disobedience, namely that they would experience destruction when the punishment promised by Allah arrived as a fitting reward for their evils.

It is also good to explain here that the Children of Israel, starting in 975 BC, had been divided into two kingdoms. First, the kingdom of Judah in the south, consisting of two tribes of the Children of Israel, namely the tribes of Judah and Benjamin. Their first king was Rehoboam, the son of Nabi Sulaiman. Second, the kingdom of Israel in the north, consisting of the other 10 tribes. Their first king was Jeroboam bin Nebat.

In 70 BC, the kingdom of Israel was attacked by the Assyrian king named Sennacherib. This king was able to enter the city of Samurra, the capital of the kingdom of Israel, capture the Children of Israel, and take them to Assyria. Thus, the kingdom of the Children of Israel collapsed after existing for 250 years.

Due to the continuous mischief of the Children of Israel, Allah mobilized the Babylonian army under the leadership of its king Bukhtanashshar, also known as Nebuchadnezzar. This army expanded its territory by killing, plundering, and robbing the inhabitants of the conquered lands. They attacked the Children of Israel, killing their scholars and leaders, destroying and burning the Torah, and even destroying their holy city, Baitul Makdis (Jerusalem).

That was the fate suffered by the Children of Israel because they had deviated from the guidance of Allah's revelation and tended to follow the desires of their lusts. They even experienced a worse fate, namely that some of the Children of Israel were taken to Babylon. They were captured three times by Nebuchadnezzar. The third and final captivity occurred in 558 BC. As a result of Nebuchadnezzar's attack, the kingdom of Judah collapsed.
text.5:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah revealed to Musa (peace be upon him), as written in the Torah, that the Children of Israel would cause mischief twice in the land of Palestine, so Allah would incite their enemies to kill, plunder, and destroy their land.

After repenting, Allah released them from this misery, their kingdom was restored, and they were granted wealth and power, both in terms of possessions and strength in terms of offspring and national defense.

However, they returned to causing mischief, so Allah Almighty incited their enemies again to destroy it. This is a punishment in this world, and in the Hereafter they will receive the torment of Hell.

Among their acts of disobedience were:

First, disregarding Allah's commands and changing the contents of the Torah.

Second, their abominations of killing Zakaria and Yahya, and their attempts to kill Nabi Isa (peace be upon him).

They committed these acts of disobedience with arrogance and displayed haughtiness. This shows that the evils they committed had exceeded the limits of humanity.

Allah then explained the consequences that would befall them because of the first act of disobedience, namely that they would experience destruction when the punishment that Allah had promised arrived as a fitting reward for their evil deeds.

It is also good to explain here that the Children of Israel, starting in 975 BC, had been divided into two kingdoms. First, the kingdom of Judah in the south, which consisted of two tribes of the Children of Israel, namely the tribes of Judah and Benjamin. Their first king was Rehoboam, the son of Nabi Sulaiman. Second, the kingdom of Israel in the north, which consisted of the other 10 tribes. Their first king was Jeroboam bin Nebat.

In 70 BC, the kingdom of Israel was attacked by the Assyrian king named Sennacherib. This king was able to enter the city of Samaria, the capital of the kingdom of Israel, capture the Children of Israel, and take them to Assyria. Thus, the kingdom of the Children of Israel collapsed after existing for 250 years.

Because the mischief of the Children of Israel did not stop, Allah incited the Babylonian army under the leadership of its king Bukhtanashshar, also known as Nebuchadnezzar. This army expanded its territory by killing, plundering, and robbing the inhabitants of the conquered lands. They attacked the Children of Israel, killed scholars and dignitaries from among them, damaged and burned the Torah, and even destroyed their holy city, Baitul Makdis (Jerusalem).

That was the fate suffered by the Children of Israel because they had deviated from the guidance of Allah's revelation and tended to follow the desires of their lusts. They even experienced a worse fate, namely that some of the Children of Israel were taken to Babylon. They were captured three times by Nebuchadnezzar. The third and final captivity occurred in 558 BC. As a result of Nebuchadnezzar's attack, the kingdom of Judah collapsed.
text.6:
Then it is explained that Allah gave the people of Bani Israil a turn to rule again. After Cyrus Kisra of Persia, the first of the Sasan family, was able to defeat Babylon, he freed the prisoners from Bani Israil who were there, and sent them back to Palestine in 536 BC. Thus, the people of Bani Israil regained control of their land. This favor from Allah was given to Bani Israil when they had repented, obeyed the teachings of the Torah again, and realized the carelessness they had committed. They were able to rebuild their country and save their families and possessions.

Thus, they returned to being an independent nation and were able to regain control of their land and become a strong and united nation as before, which they named the Jewish kingdom. This was solely due to Allah's forgiveness and mercy.

This verse explains that as long as humans are under the guidance of revelation and walk according to His guidance, they will be able to feel the blessings of Allah that are provided in this world. They can also feel peace and happiness, tranquility of life, or the prosperity of the country.

Conversely, if humans deviate from the guidance of revelation and follow the desires of their lusts, of course they will experience a bad fate. They will no longer feel the blessings that Allah has provided in the world, and even those blessings will turn into disasters. They will not experience happiness and prosperity in community life, but will become an oppressed people and expelled from their own country.
text.7:
Allah affirms that if the Children of Israel do good, the results of that good are for themselves. However, the provision contained in this verse is not exclusive to them alone, but applies generally to all people throughout time. Thus, if people do good or perform virtuous deeds, they will feel the reward of that virtue, both in this world and in the hereafter.

The good that they will receive in this world is that they will become a strong people, able to defend themselves from the evil intentions planned by their enemies. They will have the opportunity to multiply their wealth as a means of livelihood, and continue their descendants as caliphs on earth. They will become a strong nation, able to realize a high culture to further stimulate their lives, and ensure the smooth running of their endeavors and worship to Allah swt. While the eternal happiness is paradise, full of pleasures that are provided and promised to them, as proof of Allah swt's pleasure with the good deeds they do.

If they do evil by committing acts that contradict the revelation and the very nature of their creation, such as opposing the truth and norms in their own way of life, then the consequence of their actions is the wrath of Allah upon them.

Thus, they will become a nation scattered and fragmented because they are enslaved by their desires, so that one group tries to subdue another. That is why they cannot maintain their survival and themselves from destruction and the evil intentions of their enemies. They will become an oppressed and colonized nation. While the evil they feel in the hereafter is the torment of hellfire as the most painful punishment.

Then Allah reveals again the punishment as a result of the evil deeds committed by the Children of Israel for the second time. At that time, Allah left them in a state of chaos when enemies came to conquer them. This second defeat was truly felt by them as unparalleled suffering and humiliation. The enemy forcibly and arbitrarily entered Masjidil Aqsa to plunder the wealth they had stored and destroy the symbols of their religion, as was done in the first conquest. Thus, they experienced double suffering. They experienced material suffering in the form of loss of power, property, and women who were taken captive by the enemy. They also experienced moral suffering because their holy places and symbols of religious sanctity were desecrated and destroyed.

According to history, those who destroyed them for the second time were the Romans who later controlled Palestine. They killed and captured the Jews and destroyed Baitul Makdis and other cities. The first Roman Emperor to enter Baitul Makdis was Emperor Titus in 70 AD. He burned Masjidil Aqsa, and plundered the valuables contained therein, so that in this event approximately 1 million Jews died. Furthermore, Emperor Hadrian, who ruled from 117 to 158 AD, also controlled Baitul Makdis and carried out various acts of destruction in the mosque.

Hadrian transformed this city into Aelina Capitolian (the city of Aelina). Masjidil Aqsa was demolished and a building named Jupiter Capitolina was erected on it. Then the Jewish kingdom was also destroyed so that the Jewish people no longer had a kingdom. They were scattered to all corners of the world. This event occurred in 132 AD.
text.8:
Then Allah SWT commanded them to truly be aware, repent, and hold fast to the teachings of the Torah, and to avoid acts of disobedience. By doing so, Allah would bestow His mercy upon them. This promise of Allah would certainly be fulfilled and they would surely experience it.

It is mentioned in history that in the year 614 AD, which was 483 years after the destruction of Jerusalem by Hadrian, the Persians under the leadership of Khosrau II (Kisra Barwiz) seized cities in Palestine from the Romans. They fought the Romans, oppressed the Jews, and revoked the custom of Christians throwing garbage into the Temple of Solomon. They also sold the Christians residing in Jerusalem to the Jewish people and burned their churches.

Then in the year 624 AD, the Romans under the leadership of Emperor Heraclius I were able to recapture Palestine from the Persians. Heraclius even managed to enter the interior of the Persian kingdom and extinguish the fire that the Persians worshipped.

This victory of the Romans coincided with the victory of the Muslims in the Battle of Badr against the polytheists of Mecca (Ramadan 2 AH) or January 624 AD, approximately 9 years after the Romans were defeated by the Persians. However, peace between the Romans and Persians only occurred in 628 AD, after Khosrau II was killed by his own officers. In that year, all of Palestine returned to Roman rule and the cross was returned to Jerusalem.

The Prophet Muhammad SAW, who was sent since 610 AD as a prophet bringing mercy to all the worlds, migrated to Medina in 622 AD. Upon arriving in Medina, he made an agreement with the Jews who were in the city. This agreement is known as the Charter of Medina. Its contents stated that the Jews were citizens of Medina alongside the Ansar and Muhajirin. They were allowed to continue practicing their religion. However, they betrayed and plotted to kill the Messenger of Allah. They were then fought by the Messenger of Allah, and some of them were expelled from Medina, namely Bani Nadhir.

After Umar bin Khaththab became caliph, he conquered the land of Sham (Syria) in 636 AD. The inhabitants of Jerusalem (Baitul Makdis) under the leadership of Patriarch Sophronius surrendered the city to him, and a peace charter was agreed upon and signed by both parties. Umar bin Khaththab then established a mosque at the Qibla of Masjidil Aqsa (Temple of Solomon) and cleaned the city of Jerusalem. Thus, the city of Jerusalem, which had been lost for so long, reappeared magnificently.

After the entire land of Sham, including Palestine, fell into the hands of the Muslims, Roman Emperor Heraclius I ascended a hill and faced Syria. Then he waved his hand, saying, "Farewell Syria forever."

Thus, the Jewish people were freed from the clutches, abuse, and oppression of the Romans. They were once again free to worship around the Temple of Solomon (Masjidil Aqsa). This is the mercy of Allah SWT, the Most Great.

Such is the explanation mentioned in history books. As for the Al-Qur'an, it is not explained in detail, because the Al-Qur'an is not a history book.

Meanwhile, Allah SWT continues to remind that if they repeat their disobedience, as their ancestors had done, then Allah SWT will surely send down His punishment again, even more severe.

In addition, Allah provides the torment of Hellfire as an eternal prison for them in the afterlife, because that is the punishment that is fitting for those who do not want to believe.
text.9:
Allah SWT states the special characteristics of His Book that was revealed to Prophet Muhammad SAW, namely the Al-Qur'an, by showing the function of the Book itself and its benefits for all of mankind. Among the benefits of the Al-Qur'an mentioned in this verse are:

First, the Al-Qur'an gives guidance to those who want to make it a guide to the straight path. The straight path meant in this verse is the religion of Islam, which originates from the teachings of *tauhid*, namely the belief that there is no power that can create and control the universe except Allah SWT. His power cannot be matched by anyone. He is the true Ruler of the universe, and the Being who possesses the Greatest Power.

Second, the Al-Qur'an gives good news to those who believe in Allah SWT and His Messenger, do good deeds, do whatever Allah commands, and avoid doing anything that He forbids. The good news is in the form of abundant rewards that will be received in the hereafter, as a reward for the righteous deeds they did in the world.

Third, the Al-Qur'an is a warning to those who do not believe in the Day of Judgment and do not acknowledge the existence of rewards and punishments that Allah will give on the Day of Resurrection as a reward for their actions when they lived in the world. The threat addressed to them is a painful torment as a reward for the acts of disobedience that defile their souls. This includes the People of the Book who do not acknowledge the prophethood of Prophet Muhammad SAW.
text.10:
Allah SWT states the special characteristics of His Book revealed to Prophet Muhammad SAW, namely the Al-Qur'an, by showing the function of the Book itself and its benefits for all mankind. Among the benefits of the Al-Qur'an mentioned in this verse are:

First, the Al-Qur'an gives guidance to those who want to make it a guide to the straight path. The straight path referred to in this verse is the religion of Islam, which originates from the teachings of *tauhid*, namely the belief that there is no power that can create and control this universe except Allah SWT. His power cannot be matched by anyone. He is the true Ruler of the universe, and the Being who possesses the Greatest Power.

Second, the Al-Qur'an gives good news to those who believe in Allah SWT and His Messenger, do good deeds, do whatever Allah commands, and avoid doing anything that He forbids. The good news is in the form of abundant rewards that will be received in the hereafter, as a reward for the good deeds they did in the world.

Third, the Al-Qur'an is a warning to those who do not believe in the Day of Judgment and do not acknowledge the existence of rewards and punishments that Allah will give on the Day of Resurrection as a reward for their actions when they lived in the world. The threat addressed to them is a painful torment as a reward for the acts of disobedience that defile their souls. This includes the People of the Book who do not recognize the prophethood of Prophet Muhammad SAW.
text.11:
Then Allah SWT explains that among humans there are those who curse themselves, their descendants, and even their possessions with curses and prayers containing bad wishes when they are angry, such as the prayer, "O Lord! Send down curses upon me, destroy me!" They utter these words as they would when praying to Allah with good prayers, asking to be granted health and abundant safety for themselves, their descendants, and their possessions.

If Allah SWT were to grant their bad prayers, they would certainly not be able to avoid the consequences. However, Allah SWT does not do so. This is none other than because of Allah's immense compassion. Allah SWT says:

"And if Allah were to hasten for the people the evil [they invoke] as He hastens for them the good, their term would have been ended for them." (Yunus/10: 11)

At the end of the verse, Allah SWT explains that humans have a hasty nature. When they desire something according to their heart's desire, their minds are closed to assessing what they desire, whether it is beneficial or detrimental to them. This is solely driven by the hasty nature to achieve their goals, without thinking it through carefully first. This shows that in general, humans are attracted to the outward appearance of something without examining the essence and secrets of that thing more deeply.

In this verse, there is an allusion to the Arab polytheists who deny the truth of the Al-Qur'an, because they do not want to believe in the Day of Reckoning. They prefer the world that they can enjoy directly, rather than thinking about the promises and threats that they will receive on the Day of Reckoning.
text.12:
Then Allah SWT explains the signs of His power that exist in the universe, with the intention that humans think about and contemplate all of His creations in this world. Allah SWT explains that He created night and day, each as a sign of His power. Day and night are two events that always alternate, which are very useful for the benefit of human life in carrying out religious obligations and worldly affairs. Such regular alternation is a very clear sign of Allah's power for humans. Anyone who pays attention to and thinks about the alternation of day and night will certainly be convinced that the universe is governed by rules that are very good and precise, and also shows that the governor is very thorough. Thus, humans will be guided to acknowledge the existence of the Creator of this universe and all its contents.

In addition, the alternation of day and night is a blessing that can be felt directly by humans in their daily lives. At night they can rest to relieve fatigue. Allah also makes the signs of night coming, namely the disappearance of sunlight from the western horizon, so that gradually the day becomes completely dark. This is a sign of His power. Allah makes the bright day as a sign of His power as well to give humans the opportunity to seek the necessities of life for themselves and their families. On the other hand, the change of day and night is very useful for humans to know the number of years, months, and days and their calculations, except in the north and south polar regions.

In the Al-Qur'an, Allah not only tells humans about His creation, but also provides indications to utilize it for human welfare. In connection with the sun and moon, Allah provides very clear guidance that day and night, or in other words the movement of the sun and moon, will be very useful as a benchmark in making calendars. The verse that clearly states about calendaring is verse 36 of Surah at-Taubah/9, which excerpt is as follows:

"Indeed, the number of months with Allah is twelve [lunar] months in the register of Allah [from] the day He created the heavens and the earth; of these, four are sacred. That is the correct religion..."

Another similar verse is verse 5 of Surah Yunus/10:

"It is He who made the sun a shining light and the moon a derived light and determined for it phases - that you may know the number of years and account [of time]..."

Day and night occur because of the earth's rotation on its axis which moves from west to east, which gives the impression to humans as if the sun moves from east to west. When the sun appears on the eastern horizon it is called daytime and when the sun sets on the western horizon it is called nighttime.

From the time the sun sets at one time, until the sun sets the next day is called one day and one night according to custom and assumption in the calculation of the *qamariah* year. But in the calculation of the *syamsiah* year, what is called a day and night is the time from the middle of the night until the middle of the next night.

With the emphasis on the alternation of day and night as the basis for knowing the number of years and its calculations in hoping for Allah's favor, it is clear that this verse implies the flexibility of calendaring in Islam. The calendaring system based on the alternation of day and night is arranged based only on the (apparent) movement of the sun against the earth. This system does not involve the movement of the moon against the earth at all. This is the solar calendar system (tahun *syamsiah*/ solar year) which states that one year is equal to 365 plus a quarter of the night alternating with day and vice versa. Therefore, according to this system, one year is 365 days for *basithah* years and 366 days for *kabisah* years. In general, one *syamsiah* year is the length of time from January 1 to December 31. The calculation is based on the time it takes for the earth to orbit the sun. This calendaring system is identical to the Gregorian year which is now widely used in international relations.

One year in the calculation of the *qamariah* year is the length of time from 1 Muharram to 30 Zulhijjah, which is 354 days for *basithah* years or 355 days for *kabisah* years. This similar calculation is called *hisab urfi*. The calculation of the *qamariah* year is based on the moon's orbit around the earth. From crescent moon to the next crescent moon is called 1 month, and if the crescent moon has occurred 12 times, it is considered to have completed one *qamariah* year.

This verse confirms that the Gregorian calendar system or *syamsiah* year may be used by Muslims in international relations, especially in conducting transactions and business (*muamalah*) as usual with any people nationally. The Hijri calendar system which is a lunar year can be used in a limited way to determine the times of worship, namely determining the time of 1 Ramadan, 1 Syawal, and 10 Zulhijah. It is not necessary to force the use of this Hijri year for *muamalah* life in daily interactions and transactions nationally and internationally.

In reality, the Gregorian calendar or year is also used to determine other worship times, namely prayer times, because prayer times are entirely determined by the (apparent) movement of the sun and have nothing to do with the movement of the moon against the earth.

So even though there is a verse of the Al-Qur'an that implies the use of the Hijri year (which is actually a *qamariah* year) but this verse affirms Allah's command to use any solar year for *muamalah* and in general for association with other people.
text.13:
Allah SWT explains that each human being's deeds are recorded in a book of records and remain recorded within it, like a necklace that remains around their necks. These deeds encompass good deeds and bad deeds, large and small, that humans commit based on their own choices.

The analogy of the permanence of their records in the book to the permanence of a necklace on a person's neck is a metaphor that the record will be preserved, will not be lost or erased, and will always be attributed to a person.

Furthermore, Allah SWT affirms that the book containing the record of human deeds will be brought forth from its storage on the Day of Judgment and will be shown to them, so that they can know its contents openly.

In another verse, it is explained that the task of recording human deeds is managed by angels. Allah SWT says:

"And indeed, [appointed] over you are keepers, Noble and recording, They know that which you do." (al-Infithar/82: 10-12)

The following hadith of Prophet Muhammad clarifies the same matter further:

Narrated from Al-Hasan that the Messenger of Allah SAW said, "Allah said to the Children of Adam, "O Children of Adam! We have opened the pages of the Book, and two noble angels have been appointed as representatives: one on the right, and one on the left. As for the one on the right, his job is to record your good deeds, while the one on the left records your bad deeds. So do as you please, many or few deeds, until death comes to seize you. And when you have died, I will fold the pages of the book and I will place it around your neck and it will remain with you in the grave until the Day of Judgment. On that day, the book will be brought forth and you will meet it in an open state. Read the book of records, surely on that day you will know that the book is sufficient as an accounting of your deeds." (Narrated by Ibn Jarir al-Tabari)
text.14:
This verse explains that on the Day of Judgment, humans will not be able to deny those records, because the recorders are angels who are indeed appointed by Allah, whose specific task is to record the deeds of humans. That is why Allah SWT affirms at the end of the verse that on that day, their own selves are sufficient as reckoners of their deeds. This means that all the records contained in the book are accurate enough as evidence because what is recorded in the book is a recording of their deeds. It is as if they themselves made those records. Allah says:

"And the record [of deeds] will be placed [open], and you will see the criminals fearful of that within it, and they will say, "Oh, woe to us! What is this record that leaves nothing small or great except that it has enumerated it?" And they will find what they did present [before them]. And your Lord does injustice to no one." (al-Kahf/18: 49)

Thus, there is no need for other evidence as reinforcement because all the records inscribed in the book become very convincing evidence, so that it cannot be added to or subtracted from.
text.15:
In a narration originating from Ibn 'Abbas, it is stated that this verse was revealed concerning Walid bin Mugirah when he said to the people of Mecca, "Deny Muhammad, and I will bear your sins."

In this verse, Allah SWT affirms that whoever acts in accordance with Allah's guidance and the Prophet's teachings, namely carrying out His commands and avoiding His prohibitions, has acted to save himself. He will obtain a record of his good deeds in his book. He will feel happy because he will obtain Allah's pleasure and receive abundant rewards, namely Paradise with all kinds of delightful pleasures. However, whoever goes astray, namely one who deviates from the guidance of the Qur'an, will experience loss. He will obtain a record of his bad deeds in that book. He will feel regret that is of no use and will be cast into Hell, as a fitting recompense for him.

Furthermore, Allah SWT affirms that on that day, a sinner cannot bear the sins of another. Each person is responsible for his own bad deeds, so it is impossible for someone to be burdened with sins other than his own. They will receive recompense for their deeds according to the weight of the crimes they committed.

If someone is punished for misleading others, resulting in a sentence corresponding to the sin of the person misled, it does not mean that the one who misled bears the sin of the person misled. Rather, the one who misled is considered sinful for misleading others. Therefore, he is punished according to his own sin, and added to it is the sin of misleading others.

Allah SWT says:

(Their utterances) that they may bear their own burdens in full on the Day of Resurrection and some of the burdens of those whom they mislead without knowledge. (an-Nahl/16: 25)

And Allah's saying:

And they will surely bear their own loads, and other loads besides their own. (al-'Ankabut/29: 13)

At the end of this verse, it is mentioned that Allah will not punish a person or a people before sending a messenger. This means that Allah will not impose punishment on those who commit an act except after sending a messenger to recite and explain the provisions of the punishment. Thus, this verse is regarded as the basis of legality in Islamic criminal law. This means that all acts threatened with punishment must first be promulgated through legislative means that can guarantee that this regulation is known to all people. It also means that socialization of legislation is important.

This verse also contains the meaning that Allah will not destroy a people for their sins before sending a messenger who gives warning and conveys Allah's Sharia to them, and gives threats if they rebel and remain in their rebellion.

Allah SWT says:

Every time a group (of disbelievers) is cast therein, its keepers ask them, "Did there not come to you a warner?" They will say, "Yes, a warner did come to us, but we denied (him) and said, 'Allah has not sent down anything. You are not but in great error.'" (al-Mulk/67: 8-9)

And His saying:

Did We not grant you life long enough so that whoever would remember could remember therein, and a warner had come to you? Then taste (the punishment), for there will be no helper for the wrongdoers. (Fathir/35: 37)
text.16:
Then Allah SWT explains that when He wills to destroy a town, He commands those who live luxuriously in that town to obey Allah. The meaning is that if a people have committed widespread disobedience and evil, and deserve to be punished, then Allah SWT, in His justice, does not immediately inflict punishment before giving a warning to their leaders to stop the disobedience and evil of their people and immediately return to obedience to the teachings of Allah.

However, from history we know that those who are far from Allah's guidance do not want to listen to the warning, but instead become rebellious and oppose it. Allah then destroys them from the face of the earth with various punishments, whether in the form of natural disasters or other disasters. That is Allah's inevitable decree. Allah destroys that town utterly, so that nothing remains, neither their houses nor their wealth.
text.17:
Allah then recounts the stories of peoples who suffered the same fate after Noah. They were destroyed because of their disobedience to the messengers of Allah who were tasked with stopping them and inviting them to return to obedience to Allah. This verse serves as a reaffirmation of the previous verse, that every people who persist in disobedience after the arrival of a messenger who gives them warning, will surely experience the same bad fate as previous communities.

At the end of this verse, Allah SWT mentions that this similar recompense is a wise and just recompense, because Allah has given warning and knows their actions. Allah is All-Seeing of the sins of His servants.
text.18:
Allah SWT categorizes humanity into two groups: those who love the life of this world, and those who love the life of the hereafter.

In this verse, Allah SWT mentions the first group, while the second group is mentioned in the following verse. When mentioning the first group, Allah SWT states that whoever desires the life of this world with its pleasures that they can experience, then Allah SWT hastens their desires in this world according to His will. But in the hereafter, they will receive nothing except the torment of hellfire.

This statement is addressed to those who do not believe in the Day of Resurrection and the Day of Judgment, so they are convinced that there is no life after this worldly life. That is why they are so greedy for worldly wealth and luxury, even though the life of this world and its pleasures are temporary. Therefore, the life of this world and its luxury are described by Allah as something that can be obtained and felt immediately, but also quickly vanishes and ends. Allah says:

"And let not the disbelievers ever think that [because] We extend their time [of enjoyment] it is better for them. We only extend it for them so that they may increase in sin, and for them is a humiliating punishment." (ali 'Imran/3: 178)

Then Allah SWT threatens them with the threat of Hell as a fitting reward for them. In this world, they will experience deep sadness because of parting with the worldly luxuries that they love so much when death comes to snatch them away. Meanwhile, in the hereafter, they will experience the most severe suffering and regret the despicable deeds they committed in the world.
text.19:
In this verse, Allah swt mentions the second group. Allah swt states that whoever desires the Hereafter and strives towards it with sincerity while remaining a believer, then he is the one whose efforts will receive a good reward. What is meant by those who desire the Hereafter are those who aspire to the happiness of life in the Hereafter, and strive to obtain it by obeying Allah's guidance and avoiding the demands of their desires (hawa nafsu). Such a person, during his life in the world, considers the pleasures and luxuries of life to be blessings from Allah that must be thanked for and used as a means to worship Him.

That is why at the end of this verse, Allah swt affirms that such a person will receive a reward from Allah with abundant blessings, as a reward for his righteous deeds and his steadfastness in resisting the desires of his ego (hawa nafsu). He will be admitted into the Paradise of Firdaus and will abide there forever.

In this verse, three conditions are mentioned that must be fulfilled in order for a person to achieve eternal happiness, namely:

1.  Having the will to perform an action by prioritizing the happiness of the Hereafter above worldly interests.

2.  Performing righteous deeds as a manifestation of his intention to obtain the happiness of the Hereafter by obeying Allah's commands and always drawing closer to Him.

3.  Being a believer (mukmin), because faith (iman) is the basis for the acceptance or rejection of deeds. A person whose heart is empty of faith will not be able to receive that eternal happiness.
text.20:
Then Allah SWT affirms that both groups will be showered with His bounty. Meaning, both the group that loves worldly life and the group that prefers the happiness of the Hereafter will be given sustenance and allowed to develop offspring. Allah's vast generosity is not hindered by a person's denial of Him. Therefore, both groups can taste the pleasures of life in this world, according to their respective efforts. However, the two groups will not experience the same love from Allah. Those who prioritize worldly life and forget the Hereafter will enter Hell Jahannam as a fitting place for them. Meanwhile, those who prioritize the Hereafter and do not forget worldly life will enter Paradise as a place full of happiness and endless pleasures. Allah says:

"But seek, through that which Allah has bestowed upon you, the home of the Hereafter; and [yet], do not forget your share of the world." (al-Qashash/28: 77)
text.21:
Furthermore, Allah swt commands all people to pay attention to the generosity He has bestowed upon these two groups. Allah swt favors some groups over others. From each group, people will learn lessons, because even though each strives to seek sustenance and worldly pleasures, the results are different. The blessings of Allah given to those who prioritize worldly life cause them to become more ungrateful to the One who bestows those blessings. Conversely, the blessings given to those who prioritize the afterlife make them increasingly grateful to the One who bestows those blessings.

Allah swt says:

"And it is He who has made you successors upon the earth and has raised some of you above others in degrees [of rank] that He may try you through what He has given you." (al-An'am/6: 165)

And His saying:

"It is We who have apportioned among them their livelihood in the life of this world and have raised some of them above others in degrees, that some of them may make use of others [in service]." (az-Zukhruf/43: 32)

From the above explanation, it can be understood that everyone should prioritize the afterlife because it is of a higher degree and more excellent than worldly life. Regarding life in the afterlife, this is described in a hadith:

The Prophet saw said, "Indeed, the person with a high degree will see a noble place in the afterlife, just as you see a star in the height of the sky." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri)
text.22:
Allah SWT forbids mankind from deifying anything other than Allah, such as worshipping idols and the spirits of ancestors, even with the intention of drawing closer to Him. Also included in what is forbidden is acknowledging the existence of any power other than Allah that can influence oneself, or performing concrete actions, such as worshipping objects, or other unseen forces that are considered gods. This prohibition is directed at all mankind so that they do not go astray and regret doing something that should not be done to their Creator. They should be grateful for the blessings of Allah that have been bestowed upon them, not associate partners with Him, because there is no helper for mankind other than Allah.

Allah SWT says:

"If Allah helps you, none can overcome you; and if He forsakes you, who is there after that that can help you?" (ali 'Imran/3: 160)
text.23:
In this verse, Allah commands all mankind to pay attention to several factors related to faith. These factors are:

First, that humans should not worship any god other than Allah. Included in the meaning of worshipping gods other than Allah is believing in the existence of other powers that can influence the soul and body other than those that come from Allah.

Everything that exists, visible or invisible, is Allah's creation. Therefore, the only One who deserves the highest respect is the Being who created the universe and all its contents. He is the One who gives life and blessings to all His creatures. So, if there are people who worship objects or supernatural powers other than Allah, it means they have gone astray, because all those objects are His creations, which have no power to provide benefits and are powerless to ward off harm, so they do not deserve to be worshipped.

Second, that humans should do good to their parents. The mention of this command after the command to worship only Allah is intended to make people understand how important it is to do good to parents. It is also intended to make them grateful for the kindness of their parents, how heavy the suffering they have felt, both when giving birth and when struggling to earn a living, nurturing, and educating their children with love. Therefore, it is fitting that doing good to parents is made the most important obligation among other obligations, and Allah places it in the second order after the obligation of humans to worship only Him.

Allah says:

And worship Allah and associate nothing with Him, and to parents do good. (an-Nisa'/4: 36)

Conversely, a child who is disobedient to his parents is declared a sinner, whose sin is placed in the second order, after the sin of those who associate Allah with other gods.

Allah swt says:

Say, "Come, I will recite what your Lord has prohibited to you. [He commands] that you not associate anything with Him, and to parents, good treatment. (al-An'am/6: 151)

Allah swt commands humans to do good to their parents for the following reasons:

1. The love and efforts of both parents have been poured out on their children so that they become pious children and avoid the path of error. Therefore, it is fitting that this unparalleled love and tireless effort receive a response from their children by treating them well and being grateful for their good deeds.

2. Children are a part of the soul of both parents.

3. From infancy to adulthood, the growth and education of children is the responsibility of their parents. Therefore, children should respect and do good to their parents.

In short, it can be said that the most abundant blessings received by humans are the blessings of Allah, after that the blessings received from their parents. They are also the second cause of the existence of children, while Allah is the first (real) cause. That is why Allah swt places the obligation to do good to parents in the second order after the obligation of humans to worship only Allah.

After that, Allah swt stipulates that if one or both of the parents have reached old age, so that they experience physical weakness and can no longer earn a living, they must live with their children, in order to receive sustenance and protection. It is the obligation of their children to treat them with love and patience, and to respect them as a form of gratitude for the blessings they have received from them.

In this verse, there are several provisions and etiquette that children must pay attention to towards their parents, including:

1. A child should not utter dirty and harsh words, even if it is just the word "ugh" to his parents, because of their attitudes or actions that are not pleasing. Such a situation should be responded to with patience, just as their parents treated them when caring for and educating them when they were young.

2. A child should not scold or yell at his parents, because the scolding will hurt their feelings. Scolding parents means uttering harsh words when the child rejects or blames their opinions, because they do not agree with his opinion. The prohibition of scolding in this verse is a reinforcement of the prohibition of saying "ugh" which is usually uttered by a child to his parents when he does not agree with their opinion.

3. The child should utter noble words to his parents. Noble words are good words and spoken with respect, which depict good manners and full appreciation for others. Therefore, if a child disagrees with his parents, he should still show a polite and respectful attitude.

(24) Then Allah swt commands the Muslims to be humble and full of love towards their parents. What is meant by humility in this verse is obeying what they command as long as the command does not conflict with the provisions of religion. A child's obedience to his parents is a sign of his love and respect for them, especially when they are in dire need of their child's help.

It is emphasized that humility must be done with love, not made up just to cover up flaws or avoid shame in front of others. Humility should really be done because of awareness that arises from the conscience.

At the end of the verse, Allah swt commands the Muslims to pray for their parents, so that they are given an abundance of Allah's love as a reward for their love in educating them when they were children.

There are several hadith of the Prophet saw that command Muslims to be devoted to their parents:

It is narrated from 'Abdullah bin 'Umar that a man came to the Prophet saw asking for permission to join him in fighting, then the Prophet said, "Are your parents still alive?" The man replied, "Yes." The Prophet said, "Then strive by being devoted to your parents." (Narrated by Muslim and al-Bukhari in the chapter al-adab)

A child is not considered to have repaid the kindness of his parents, unless he finds them in a state of being slaves, then he ransoms them and frees them. (Narrated by Muslim and others from Abu Hurairah)

I asked Rasulullah saw, "Which deed is most loved by Allah and His Messenger?" Rasulullah replied, "Performing prayer on time." I asked, "Then which deed again?" Rasulullah replied, "Doing good to both parents." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Ibn Mas'ud)

In the verse interpreted above, it is not explained who should be given priority in receiving devotion between the two parents. However, in a hadith it is explained that devotion to the mother takes precedence over the father, as narrated in Sahih al-Bukhari and Muslim:

It is narrated from Abu Hurairah that Rasulullah saw was asked, "Who is most entitled to the best treatment from me?" Rasulullah replied, "Your mother." The man asked, "Who else?" Rasulullah replied, "Your mother." The man asked, "Who else?" Rasulullah replied, "Your mother." The man asked, "Who else?" Rasulullah replied, "Your father." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Devotion to parents is not enough to be done when they are still alive, but continues even after they have passed away. As for the procedures, it is mentioned in the hadith narrated by Ibn Majah:

That Rasulullah saw was asked, "Is there still devotion to my parents, after they have passed away?" Rasulullah saw replied, "Yes, there are still four things, praying for the parents to Allah, asking for forgiveness for them, fulfilling their promises, and respecting their friends and connecting the ties of brotherhood with people who have no family relationship with you except from their side. So this is the remaining devotion that you must fulfill, as devotion to them after they have passed away." (Narrated by Ibn Majah from Abu Usaid)
text.24: Then Allah swt commanded the Muslims to be humble and full of affection towards their parents. What is meant by humility in this verse is obeying what they command as long as the command does not contradict the provisions of religion. A child's obedience to their parents is a sign of their love and respect for them, especially when they are in dire need of their child's help. It is emphasized that this humility must be done with genuine affection, not feigned merely to cover up flaws or avoid embarrassment in front of others. This humility should truly be done out of a consciousness that arises from the conscience. At the end of the verse, Allah swt commands the Muslims to pray for their parents, so that they may be given an abundance of Allah's love as a reward for their love in raising them when they were children. So this is the remaining devotion that you must fulfill, as devotion to them after they have passed away." (Narrated by Ibn Majah from Abu Usaid)
text.25:
Allah SWT then warned the Muslims to truly pay attention to the matter of being devoted to both parents and not to consider it a trivial matter. It was explained that Allah is All-Knowing of what moves in their hearts, whether they are truly devoted to both parents with affection and full awareness, or whether it is only an outward statement, while in their hearts they are actually disobedient and rebellious. That is why Allah promises that if they truly do good, that is, truly obey Allah's demands and are devoted to both parents, then He will grant them forgiveness for actions that exceed the limits of His provisions. Allah is Most Forgiving to whoever wants to repent and return to obeying His commands.

In this verse, there is a good promise addressed to those whose hearts are open to being devoted to their parents. Conversely, there is a severe threat addressed to those who underestimate it, especially those who deliberately disobey their parents.
text.26:
In this verse, Allah swt commands the Muslims to fulfill the rights of close relatives, the poor, and those who are on a journey. The rights that must be fulfilled are: strengthening the bonds of brotherhood and affection, visiting their homes and behaving politely, and helping to alleviate the suffering they experience. If any of the close relatives, or the poor and those on a journey, need funds for their living expenses, then they should be given sufficient assistance to meet their needs. Those on a journey whose suffering deserves to be alleviated are those who are traveling for purposes justified by religion. Such people need to be helped and assisted so that they can achieve their goals.

At the end of the verse, Allah swt forbids the Muslims from being extravagant, which is spending wealth without careful calculation, thus becoming wasteful. This prohibition aims to ensure that Muslims manage their expenses with the utmost care, so that what is spent is in accordance with their needs and income. Muslims should also not spend wealth on those who are not entitled to receive it, or give wealth in excess of what is appropriate.

Further explanation of how Muslims should spend their wealth is mentioned in the word of Allah swt:

And [they are] those who, when they spend, are neither extravagant nor miserly, but ever, between that, [justly] moderate. (al-Furqan/25: 67)

As for the explanation that clarifies the meaning contained in the verse regarding the prohibition of extravagance, which means wastefulness, it can be seen in the hadith of the Prophet as follows:

It was narrated from Abdullah bin Umar, he said, "The Messenger of Allah saw Saad while he was performing wudu, then the Messenger of Allah said, "How extravagant is your wudu, O Saad!" Saad said, "Is there extravagance in wudu?" The Messenger of Allah said, "Yes, even if you are at a flowing river." (Riwayat Ibnu Majah)

It was narrated from Anas bin Malik that he said, "A man from Bani Tamim came to the Messenger of Allah swt and said, "O Messenger of Allah! I am a man of wealth, with many family members, children, and guests who are always present, so explain to me how I should spend my wealth, and how I should act." Then the Messenger of Allah said, "You should pay zakat from your wealth if you have wealth, because indeed zakat is a purification that purifies you, maintain the ties of kinship with your relatives, and you should know about the rights of those who ask for help, neighbors, and the poor. Then the man said, "O Messenger of Allah! Can you reduce that obligation for me?" The Messenger of Allah swt recited the verse: And give the relative his right, and [also] the poor and the traveler, and do not spend wastefully. Then the man said, "That is enough for me, O Messenger of Allah, if I have paid zakat to your zakat collector, then I am free from the obligation of zakat that must be paid to Allah and His Messenger," then the Messenger of Allah said, "Yes, if you have paid the zakat to my collector, you are free from that obligation and you will receive its reward, and whoever replaces it with another will be sinful." (Riwayat Ahmad)
text.27:
Then, Allah SWT states that spendthrifts are the brothers of Satan. This kind of expression is commonly used by the Arabs. Someone who habitually follows the rules of a group or follows in their footsteps is called a brother of that group. So, people who waste their wealth are people who follow in the footsteps of Satan. What is meant by spendthrifts in this verse are people who squander their wealth in acts of disobedience that are certainly outside of Allah's commands. People like these are called companions of Satan. In the world, they are tempted by Satan, and in the Hereafter, they will be thrown into Hell.

Allah SWT says:
