However, this did not affect the steadfastness of the Messenger of Allah and his followers, even though they were forced to migrate. The promise of victory from Allah will come in due time, and the enemies of Allah will suffer a great defeat.

It needs to be explained that the punishment of annihilating the disobedient, as happened to the people of 'Ad, Thamud, the people of Lot, and others, known as *azab al-isti'shal* (punishment by annihilation), is no longer applied after the Messenger of Allah Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) was sent because he is a bringer of mercy to all mankind, and there is hope that the disbelieving Quraysh or their descendants will embrace Islam.

Allah Almighty says:

"But Allah would not punish them while you, [O Muhammad], are among them, and Allah would not punish them while they seek forgiveness." (al-Anfal/8: 33)
text.78:
This verse commands the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) to establish prayer from after the sun has passed its zenith until the darkness of the night, and to establish the Fajr (dawn) prayer. The intention is to establish the five daily prayers, namely, Zuhr, Asr, Maghrib, Isha, and Fajr.

Performing the five daily prayers means performing and fulfilling them completely with their pillars and conditions, continuously performed, in accordance with Allah's command, outwardly and inwardly. What is meant by outwardly is performing the prayer according to the provisions established by religion. While inwardly means performing the prayer with full humility (khushu'), because of feeling the greatness and power of Allah who controls and creates this entire universe. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) commanded the Muslims to worship Allah as if they were seeing Allah. That is Ihsan, as the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"Ihsan is to worship Allah as if you see Him, and if you cannot see Him, then indeed He sees you." (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

When a servant of Allah performs the five daily prayers, it means that he has performed one of the pillars of Islam, according to the hadith of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him):

"Islam is built upon five [pillars]: testifying that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, establishing prayer, paying zakat, fasting Ramadan, and performing Hajj to the House for those who are able to make the journey." (Narrated by Muslim from 'Abdullah bin 'Umar r.a.)

In this verse, it is explained that the Fajr prayer is witnessed by the angels. The meaning is that at the time of Fajr, the angels guarding the night meet with the angels guarding the day for a change of duty, and both report to Allah that the person concerned was performing prayer when they left him, as explained in the hadith of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him):

From Abu Hurairah, that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "Angels of the night and day alternate in their duties. They gather at the time of Fajr prayer and Asr prayer. Then the angels who guarded you at night ascend, and the Lord asks them (while Allah knows more about you), "How were My servants when you left them?" The angels reply, "We came to them, they were in prayer, and we left them, they were also in prayer." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Regarding the virtue of performing the Fajr prayer at the beginning of its time, ar-Razi said, "Indeed, at the time of Fajr, people witness the signs of Allah's power and the greatness of His wisdom in the heavens and on earth. At that time, the bright sunlight sweeps away the darkness of the night, at that time the sleeping person wakes up and his senses return to work after being lulled to sleep."
text.79:
This verse commands the Messenger of Allah and the Muslims to wake up at night to perform the Tahajjud prayer. This verse is the first verse that commands the Messenger of Allah to perform the night prayer as an addition to the obligatory prayers. This night prayer is explained by the hadith of the Prophet saw:

That the Prophet saw was asked, "Which prayer is the most excellent after the obligatory prayers (the five daily prayers)?" The Messenger of Allah saw replied, "The Tahajjud prayer." (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

From the authentic hadiths of the Prophet, narrated from 'A'ishah and Ibn 'Abbas, it is understood that the Prophet Muhammad saw woke up to perform the Tahajjud prayer after he had slept. This habit of the Prophet can be used as a legal basis that the Tahajjud prayer is sunnah (recommended) to be performed by someone after sleeping for a while at night, then in the middle of the night he wakes up to perform the Tahajjud prayer.

Then Allah swt explains that the law of the Tahajjud prayer is an additional worship for the Messenger of Allah in addition to the five daily prayers. Therefore, the law for the Messenger of Allah is obligatory, while for his people it is sunnah.

In this verse, the purpose of the Tahajjud prayer for the Prophet Muhammad is explained, so that Allah swt can place him in *maqaman mahmudan* (in a praiseworthy place).

What is meant by *maqaman mahmudan* is the intercession of the Messenger of Allah saw on the Day of Judgment. On that day, humans experience an unparalleled state of distress. The only thing that can relieve and alleviate humans from that very difficult situation is the request of the Prophet Muhammad saw to his Lord, so that that person is relieved and alleviated from his suffering.

Narrated by at-Tirmidhi from Abu Hurairah that the Messenger of Allah saw said, "The meaning of *maqaman mahmudan* in this verse is my intercession." (hasan sahih hadith)

Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari said that most scholars said, "What is meant by *maqaman mahmudan* is a position used by the Messenger of Allah saw on the Day of Judgment to intercede for humans, so that Allah swt alleviates the distress and difficulties they experience on that day."

Narrated by an-Nasa'i, al-Hakim, and a group of hadith scholars from Hudzaifah, "Allah gathers humans on a vast land on the Day of Judgment, they all stand and no one speaks on that day except with His permission. The first people whose names are called are Muhammad, then Muhammad prays to Him. This is what is meant by *maqaman mahmudan* in this verse.

Narrated by al-Bukhari from Jabir bin 'Abdullah that the Messenger of Allah saw said:

Whoever reads the prayer after finishing hearing the adhan, "O my Lord, Lord of this perfect call and the prayer that is performed, grant Muhammad *wasilah* and excellence and raise him to *al-maqam al-mahmud* (the praiseworthy position) that You have promised him," then he will obtain my intercession.

Narrated from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri that the Messenger of Allah saw said, "I am the leader of the descendants of Adam on the Day of Judgment. I do not boast, and in my hand is held *liwa'ul hamdi* (the banner of praise) I do not boast. There is no prophet on that day, from Adam to the other prophets, except under my banner, I am the first person to come out of the earth, and I do not boast. Humans at that time are frightened by three frightening things. Then they come to Adam. They say, "You are our father, help us to your Lord." Adam replies, "I have a sin that caused me to be sent down to earth. Come to Noah!" so they come to Noah. (after they complained to Noah about their problem), Noah said, "I have prayed for the inhabitants of the earth so that they are destroyed. But come to Abraham. So they come to Abraham. Abraham then tells them to come to Moses.

Moses said, "I once killed someone. Come to Jesus." Jesus then said, "I was once worshiped besides Allah. Just come to Muhammad." So they come to me. I then go with them, then I hold the ring of the door of heaven, then I pull it. Then I am asked, "Who is that?" I replied, "Muhammad." Then they opened the door for me, and said, "Welcome." then I fell prostrate. Then Allah inspired me to praise, glorify, and magnify Him. Then I was ordered, "Raise your head, ask! You will be given. Ask for the right of intercession, then you will be allowed to intercede. And speak, your words will be heard.

That is the praiseworthy station, which Allah said, "May your Lord give you a praiseworthy station." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi)

From the verses and hadiths above, it is understood that the Prophet Muhammad saw, by performing the Tahajjud prayer, will be raised by Allah swt to a place and position that is praised by mankind, the angels, and Allah Tabaraka wa Taala, namely the position to ask for intercession for mankind when they are in the Padang Mahsyar (the Gathering Place) with the permission of Allah. Mankind indeed deserves intercession because of their good deeds and character during their life in the world, namely that their sins are forgiven by God or that their status is raised.

In another word of Allah, it is explained that waking up in the middle of the night to perform the Tahajjud prayer and reading the Qur'an with devotion will strengthen faith and build oneself. Allah swt says:

O you who wraps himself [in clothing], Arise [to pray] the night, except for a little - Half of it - or a little less than that, Or a little more. And recite the Qur'an with measured recitation. Indeed, We will cast upon you a heavy word. Indeed, the hours of the night are more effective for concurrence [of heart and tongue] and more suitable for words. (al-Muzzammil/73: 1-6)
text.80:
At-Tirmidhi narrated from Ibn 'Abbas that the Prophet was in Mecca, then Allah commanded him to migrate. Then this verse was revealed.

Allah swt commanded the Prophet Muhammad saw to recite the supplication mentioned in this verse, which means, "O my Lord, admit me to the place You desire, both in this world and the Hereafter, and place me in the place You desire, both in this world and the Hereafter."

Among the examples of the Messenger of Allah entering a place correctly is when he and his companions entered the city of Medina as migrants from Mecca, entered the city of Mecca at the time of its conquest, entered the grave after death, and entered places pleasing to Allah, such as entering mosques, one's own home, the homes of friends, and acquaintances after asking permission, and so on. Exiting from all places desired by Allah, such as leaving the city of Mecca at the time of migration, exiting from the grave at the time of resurrection, or exiting from all places disliked by Allah, such as cities that are places for committing acts of disobedience, and so on.

Allah swt also commanded the Prophet to pray to Him to be made a person who possesses compelling arguments and reasons that can be accepted and, when preaching, can satisfy those who listen, so that their faith increases. If the listener is a disbeliever, their hearts become softened and they are willing to embrace Islam. As an answer to the Prophet Muhammad's prayer, Allah explained that He protects the Prophet from all kinds of human deception and will grant him victory over the disbelievers, as stated in His word:

And Allah will protect you from the people. Indeed, Allah does not guide the disbelieving people. (al-Ma'idah/5: 67)
text.81:
Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to convey to the polytheists that the truth has indeed come, namely the Qur'an, faith, and Islam. As for falsehood, which is polytheism and disbelief, it will be destroyed. Falsehood will not last long because it has no true foundation.

In another verse, Allah SWT says:

"Nay, We hurl the truth against falsehood, and it knocks out its brain, and behold, falsehood perishes! And woe to you for that which you describe (to Allah)." (al-Anbiya'/21: 18)

Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from 'Abdullah bin Mas'ud, when the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) entered the city of Mecca at the time of the conquest of the city, there were 360 idols around the Ka'bah. Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) poked the idols with a piece of wood in his hand, and said:

"The truth has come and falsehood has vanished. Surely, falsehood is ever bound to vanish. The truth has come, and falsehood will neither begin nor return." (Riwayat al-Bukhari dan Muslim)
text.82:
This verse explains that Allah SWT revealed the Qur'an to Muhammad as a cure for diseases of the heart, namely shirk, disbelief (kufr), and hypocrisy (nifaq). The Qur'an is also a mercy for Muslims because it guides them, so they enter Paradise and are spared from Allah's punishment.

The Qur'an freed the Muslims from ignorance, so they became a nation that dominated the world during the Umayyad and Abbasid caliphates. Then they became a backward people again because they neglected the teachings of the Qur'an. They used to be a respected people, but then became pawns used as bait by enemies in world affairs. Because they used to implement the teachings of the Qur'an, their country became the center of the world of science, world trade, and so on, and once lived prosperously and happily. This verse warns Muslims that they will be able to play a role in the world again if they are willing to follow the Qur'an and adhere firmly to its teachings in all areas of life.

Conversely, if they are unwilling to implement the teachings of the Qur'an seriously, prioritize personal interests over the interests of religion and society, and only care about worldly life, then Allah will make their enemies rulers over them, so that they become foreigners or slaves in their own country.

The experience of Muslims is bitter enough as a result of neglecting the teachings of the Qur'an. The Qur'an commands them to unite and consult (musyawarah), but they are divided over small and trivial khilafiah issues, while important and major issues are ignored.

This verse also reminds Muslims that for the wrongdoers (zalim), namely those who are disbelieving, commit shirk, and are hypocritical, the Qur'an will only add to their loss, because every teaching brought by the Qur'an will be rejected by them. In fact, if accepted, it would certainly benefit them.
text.83:
In this verse, Allah swt explains the general characteristic of humans, which is that when they are given blessings, such as wealth, power, victory, and so on, they no longer want to submit and obey Him; in fact, they distance themselves. Conversely, when afflicted with difficulties, misery, poverty, and defeat, they despair and feel they will no longer obtain anything. They should not despair, but rather continue to do good deeds and strive to obtain Allah's help, because according to the teachings of the Al-Qur'an, those who despair of Allah's mercy have denied His mercy.

Other verses that explain the state of humans when receiving Allah's mercy are His words:

And when harm touches man, he calls upon Us, whether lying on his side or sitting or standing; but when We remove his harm from him, he passes on as if he had never called upon Us for relief from harm that touched him. (Yunus/10: 12)
text.84:
Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to convey to his people that they should work according to their respective potentials and inclinations. Everyone is welcome to work according to their nature, character, will, and tendencies. Allah SWT, as the Ruler of the universe, knows who among mankind follows the truth and who among them follows falsehood. All will later be given a just decision.

Allah says regarding the command to work:

Say, "O my people, work according to your position; [for] indeed, I am working. And you are going to know who will have succession in the home. Indeed, the wrongdoers will not succeed." (al-An'am/6: 135)
text.85:
The Jews asked the Prophet Muhammad about the *ruh* that can enliven the body, what its essence is, and whether it can be resurrected. Then Allah commanded the Prophet to answer that question by saying that the matter of the *ruh* is Allah's affair, only He knows everything, and He alone created it.

The word *ruh* in the Qur'an has three meanings:

First: What is meant by *ruh* is the Qur'an. As Allah says:

And thus We have revealed to you (Muhammad) a *ruh* (the Qur'an) by Our command. (ash-Shura/42: 52)

This understanding is in accordance with the content of verse 82 of Surah al-Isra', which explains that the Qur'an is a cure and mercy for those who believe. It is also in accordance with verse 87 of the same surah, which explains that if Allah wills, He will surely eliminate the Qur'an that has been revealed to the Prophet Muhammad. Thus, the Prophet will not obtain defense.

Second: The angel Gabriel. In the Qur'an, many words of *ruh* are interpreted as Gabriel a.s., as in the word of Allah swt.

Brought down by ar-*Ruh* al-Amin (Gabriel), into your heart (Muhammad) so that you may be among the warners. (ash-Shu'ara'/26: 193-194)

And the word of Allah swt:

...then We sent to her Our *ruh* (Gabriel), and he appeared before her in the form of a perfect man. (Maryam/19: 17)

Third: Meaning the *ruh* that is in the body, which is the source of life for living beings. According to the majority of scholars (Jumhur Ulama), the word *ruh* in this verse is the *ruh* that is in the body (soul/life). The word of Allah:

And (remember Maryam) who guarded her chastity, so We breathed into her (ruh) from Us; and We made her and her son a sign (of the greatness of Allah) for all the worlds. (al-Anbiya'/21: 91)

The opinion that equates *ruh* with *nafs* (soul/life) is the opinion widely held by scholars (jumhur) and is in accordance with the reason this verse was revealed. Allah says:

So when I have proportioned him and breathed into him of My (created) *ruh*, then fall down to him in prostration. (al-Hijr/15: 29)

The verses above invite mankind to understand the contents of the Qur'an truthfully, so as not to go astray to the wrong path. Conversely, those who do not try to understand the contents of the Qur'an will not be able to use it as a guide in life, and they even take actions and deeds that can distance them from understanding its verses correctly. They ask the Prophet saw about things that humans cannot possibly know, which are actually useless to know, except only to test the Prophet.

Allah swt in this verse states that He only gives humans very little knowledge about the *ruh*. However, some scholars have tried to explore the essence of the *ruh*. Among them are:

1. The *ruh* is a kind of light matter (*jisim, nurani*) that descends to earth from the high realm, its nature is different from matter that can be seen and touched.

2. The *ruh* flows in the human body, just as water flows in a flower, or as fire in embers. The *ruh* gives life to a person's body as long as the body is able and capable of receiving it, and there is nothing that hinders its flow. When the body is no longer able and capable of receiving the *ruh*, so that its flow is hindered in the body, then the body dies. This opinion was put forward by ar-Razi and Ibnul Qayyim. Meanwhile, Imam al-Gazali and Abu Qasim ar-Ragib al-Asfahani are of the opinion that the *ruh* is not matter and something that is shaped, but it is only something that depends on the body to manage and resolve the body's interests.

The best attitude of Muslims about the *ruh* is to follow this word of Allah, that the essence of the *ruh* cannot be reached by human thought, because only Allah knows it for sure. What needs to be believed is that the *ruh* exists. Allah only gives its symptoms to humans themselves, even knowing the existence of the *ruh*, and appreciating its symptoms. So what needs to be researched and studied seriously are the symptoms of the *ruh*, which are carried out in psychology. Studying the symptoms of the soul is even something that Allah asks for in His word:

And (also) in yourselves. Then do you not see? (adz-dzariyat/51: 21)

Because only Allah knows about the essence of the *ruh*, in this verse Allah swt affirms to humans that Allah's knowledge is Most Vast, cannot be estimated, covers all kinds of knowledge, both knowledge about the real world and the unreal world, both that can be reached by the senses and that cannot. Because of Allah's love for humans, He has bestowed a small portion of that knowledge to humans, which is meaningless at all when compared to the amount of Allah's knowledge.

It is narrated that when this verse was revealed, the Jews answered, "We have been given much knowledge. We have been given the Torah. Whoever has been given the Torah, means he has been given much good." Then verse 109 of Surah al-Kahf was revealed. Allah swt says:

Say, "If the sea were ink for [writing] the words of my Lord, the sea would be exhausted before the words of my Lord were exhausted, even if We brought the like of it as a supplement." (al-Kahf/18: 109)
text.86:
This verse explains that if Allah SWT willed to retract the Quran that had been revealed and erase it from the heart of the Prophet Muhammad and from the written pages, He would certainly be able to do so easily, leaving not a trace.

The ease with which Allah SWT can erase the Quran is explained in a hadith of the Prophet SAW:

It is narrated from Ibn Mas'ud that the Messenger of Allah SAW said, "Indeed, this Quran will be lifted (erased)." Someone said, "How is that possible, when Allah has established it firmly in our hearts, and we have immortalized (written) it on written pages?" He said, "The Quran will be lifted in one night, and not a single verse will be left of it in the heart, nor in the mushaf, but all will be lifted. So, in the morning, not a single verse will remain with you." Then the Prophet recited this verse. (Narrated by Sa'id bin Manshur and al-Hakim, and declared sahih by ath-Thabrani and al-Baihaqi).

After the Quran is erased from the heart and what is written in the mushaf, at that time there will be nothing left to be used as a guide and direction to the right path. No one will be able to restore it, either in the form of a mushaf or memorization.
text.87:
However, Allah did not intend to erase the Qur'an from the Prophet's heart and the mushafs, because of His great mercy bestowed upon His servants. The Qur'an is the greatest blessing that Allah has given to mankind. He establishes the Qur'an in the hearts of people and protects it from their interference.

According to ar-Razi, there are two kinds of great blessings that Allah gives to the scholars: first, making it easy for them to acquire knowledge, and second, the permanence of knowledge in their minds and memories. With these two kinds of blessings, it is easy for people to digest the contents of the verses of the Qur'an and then carry out what He commands and stop what He forbids. Thus, they are protected from destruction in the world and the torment of hell in the hereafter.

In this verse, Allah explains that the virtue He gave to the Prophet Muhammad is so great that Allah does not want the revelation that has been revealed to him to be erased. This revelation is Allah's greatest blessing to the Messenger of Allah and the believers because it contains guidance and healing from various diseases.
text.88:
It is narrated by Ibn Ishaq and Ibn Jarir from Sa'id from Ibn 'Abbas, that Salam bin Misykam and his fellow Jews came to the Prophet Muhammad saw and said, "How can we follow you, Muhammad, when you have abandoned our qibla and the Qur'an you bring is not arranged like the Torah. Therefore, send down to us a book that we can examine. If you cannot bring it, then we will bring you something similar to what you bring." Then Allah swt revealed this verse, affirming to them that they would all be unable to create a book like the Qur'an.

The *sabab nuzul* (reason for revelation) of this verse is not agreed upon by the scholars because this surah is a Makki surah and its target audience is the Quraysh, while the Jews lived in Medina.

In this verse, Allah swt affirms the miracle of the Qur'an and its virtue, namely that the Qur'an is truly from Allah and was revealed to the Prophet Muhammad saw. As proof that the Qur'an is from Allah, not made by Muhammad as claimed by the disbelievers of Mecca and the People of the Book, Allah swt commanded the Prophet Muhammad saw to convey a challenge to those who ignore and consider the Qur'an not to be a revelation from Allah, to create a counterpart to the Qur'an. But Allah affirms that they will not be able to create a similar book. Allah says:

And if you are in doubt about what We have sent down upon Our Servant (Muhammad), then produce a surah like it and call upon your witnesses other than Allah, if you should be truthful. But if you do not - and you will never be able to - then fear the Fire whose fuel is people and stones, prepared for the disbelievers. (al-Baqarah/2: 23-24)

History shows that many Arab leaders and literary experts tried to rival and imitate the Qur'an, some even claiming to be prophets, such as Musailamah al-Kadzdzab, Thulaiha, Habalah bin Kaab, and others. However, they all failed in their efforts and even received ridicule and contempt from the community. An example is what was made by Musailamah al-Kadzdzab, which he considered to be able to rival the verses of the Qur'an:

O frog, son of two frogs, croak your voice as you wish to croak. Your upper part is in the water and your lower part is in the land.

Experts state that Musailamah's words do not contain any meaning. Among those who commented was al-Jahiz, a famous Arab literary figure who said, "I do not understand what moved Musailamah's soul to mention frogs and so on, how bad is the composition he said as a verse of the Qur'an that was revealed to the Prophet Muhammad saw."

The possibility of cooperation between jinn and humans is mentioned here to balance the Angel Jibril and the Prophet Muhammad who received the Qur'an from Allah. They cannot possibly rival it because the Qur'an comes from Allah swt.
text.89:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah conveys all kinds of evidence and arguments to mankind so that they may believe. These various proofs and arguments are revealed in the form of explanations with various styles of language, including commands, news, and stories. Likewise, the content is diverse, such as *aqidah* (creed), law, ethics, worship, stories, and so on, the truth of which cannot be refuted.

Even though Allah SWT has conveyed them in different forms and ways, and the content contains high values to achieve happiness in this world and the hereafter, the disbelievers do not believe. They continue to deny and oppose it.
text.90:
These verses explain the attitude of the Quraysh leaders towards the call of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), including Uthbah, Shaybah, Abu Sufyan, Nadhar, and others. Their attitude showed clear signs of denial and reluctance to accept the call. Consequently, no matter what evidence was presented to them, they would still not believe. They asked the Messenger of Allah for impossible things because they knew that the Messenger of Allah would not be able to do them. Thus, they had a reason not to follow the Messenger's call.

Among the requests of the disbelievers were:

1.  That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) cause springs to gush forth from the earth, even though their land was a desert.

2.  That the Messenger of Allah create a garden of dates or grapes with rivers flowing through it. With the water constantly flowing, the date and grape trees would become more fertile and yield multiple harvests.

3.  That the Messenger of Allah cause the sky to fall in pieces upon them. Their request like this is explained in another verse. Allah Almighty says:

"And [remember] when they said, "O Allah, if this [Quran] is indeed the truth from You, then rain down upon us stones from the sky or bring us a painful punishment." (al-Anfal/8: 32)

Their request is like the request of the people of Aikah (Madyan) to Prophet Shu'aib in the past, as Allah Almighty says:

"Then cause to fall upon us fragments of the sky, if you should be of the truthful." (ash-Shu'ara'/26: 187)

4.  That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) bring Allah and the angels visibly (able to be seen in reality) to them to declare directly that Muhammad is a messenger sent by Him.

5.  That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) build a house made of gold. The polytheists believed that a messenger sent by Allah should be a ruler, rich, and respected. Therefore, according to them, it was impossible for Muhammad, an orphan and poor, to be appointed as a messenger.

6.  That the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) ascend to heaven via a ladder that they could see, then descend back to earth via the same ladder carrying a book that they could read and that used their language, explaining that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah.

In reality, everything requested by the polytheists was very easy for Allah to grant; nothing is difficult or impossible for Allah to create and do. However, Allah knows that all these requests were merely fabricated, as excuses not to believe in Prophet Muhammad. The attitude of the polytheists is explained in the word of Allah Almighty:

"Indeed, those upon whom the word of your Lord has been justified will not believe, even if every sign should come to them - until they see the painful punishment." (Yunus/10: 96-97)

And the word of Allah:

"And even if We had sent down to them the angels [with the message] and the dead spoke to them and We gathered together every [created] thing before them, they would not believe unless Allah should will. But most of them, [of that], are ignorant." (al-An'am/6: 111)

Allah Almighty commanded Muhammad to convey to the polytheists that he was only a human being who was appointed as a messenger and given revelation. Allah is able to fulfill all their requests, but their requests were not granted because they were unnecessary. Even if they were granted, they still would not believe.

text.94:
This verse explains that nothing prevented the polytheists of Mecca from believing in the Prophet Muhammad when Allah revealed the revelation to him accompanied by various miracles, except for their desire that if Allah SWT sent a messenger to mankind, then that messenger should be an angel, not an ordinary human being.

The disbelievers of Mecca in particular, and disbelievers in general, were surprised why the revelation was revealed to an ordinary human being like Muhammad, even an orphan. Why wasn't it revealed to the most intelligent or richest among them, or a human being with supernatural powers, an angel, and so on. The attitude of the Meccan polytheists was the same as the attitude of those who came before them towards the messengers who were sent to them.

Allah SWT says:

"Do you wonder that a reminder has come to you from your Lord through a man from among yourselves, to warn you so that you may fear Allah and perhaps receive mercy?" (al-A'raf/7: 63)
text.95:
Allah refutes the attitude of the polytheists of Mecca by stating that if there were angels on earth who walked, thought, resided, lived in society, had desires, culture, organized themselves, and so on, then Allah SWT would have sent angels as His messengers, not humans.

This verse seems to warn the disbelievers that the messenger sent by Allah is an ordinary human being but is able to convey His religious teachings to them, understand what they want, what they feel, what is good for them, and so on. Not like angels who have no ambitions in life like humans and only carry out what Allah commands them.

Allah SWT says:

Indeed Allah conferred a great favor on the believers when He sent among them a Messenger (Muhammad) from among themselves, reciting unto them His Verses (the Qur'an), and purifying them, and instructing them (in) the Book (the Qur'an) and Al-Hikmah (the Sunnah), while before that they had been in manifest error. (ali 'Imran/3: 164)
text.96: Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah (saw) to convey His threat to the disbelievers, that Allah would be a witness over what was disputed between the Prophet and the polytheists of Mecca. Allah will be the judge who will adjudicate their case justly in the Hereafter because He knows all that they do, even what is contained within their hearts.
text.97:
Allah SWT explains in this verse that He is the One who controls and determines everything. He is the One who gives guidance and *taufik* to whomever He wills. Those who do not receive His guidance and *taufik* are those who are astray and will not obtain any helpers besides Allah.

Those who are astray will be gathered by Allah on the Day of Judgment in a place to be reckoned. They will be resurrected from their graves in a state of blindness, muteness, and deafness, just as they did not see and hear the truth that was conveyed in the world.

The Prophet SAW said:

A man asked the Messenger of Allah SAW, "O Messenger of Allah, how will people walk on their faces?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "He who made them walk on their feet is certainly able to make them walk on their faces." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Anas bin Malik)

Abu Dawud and at-Tirmidzi narrated a *hadith* from Abu Hurairah:

That people are of three types on the day they gather in the *padang Mahsyar* (the gathering place), some walk, some ride, and some walk on their faces.

After the reckoning is complete, they will be thrown into the Hell of *Jahanam* and burned with a blazing fire because every time it is about to die down, the flames are increased again. Every time their skin and bodies are burned, and their flesh is destroyed, Allah replaces them with new skin, flesh, and bodies, so that they feel an unending torment.
text.98: This verse explains that the disbelievers are punished because they deny the verses of Allah and the Day of Resurrection, saying, "Is it possible for us to be resurrected after we die, our bodies have decayed and disintegrated with the earth, and our bones are scattered into separate parts? Can those body parts be collected and brought back to life, so that we become new living beings?"
text.99:
Allah SWT refutes the opinions of those who do not believe in the Day of Resurrection by saying, do they not see and observe how Allah created them from nothingness into existence, as well as the heavens and all that is in them, and the earth with all the objects and creatures within it, including humans themselves? Do they not pay attention to all the events in the heavens and on earth? Everything was created from nothingness into existence. If Allah SWT is capable of creating everything for the first time, then surely He is also capable of creating it for the second time because redesigning is usually easier than creating for the first time. Allah has created for mankind a period of time about which there is no doubt, establishing the duration of their life in the world and in the grave, and the time when they will be resurrected. Only Allah knows the determination of those times.

Despite the evidence about the Day of Resurrection, the greatness, and the power of Allah having been presented and explained to those unjust disbelievers, they still deny and do not believe in that evidence.
text.100:
In this verse, Allah swt explains the reasons why He does not grant the requests of the wrongdoers, which is that even if granted, they still would not believe, would be stingy, and would not want to give even a small portion of their wealth to others in need. They fear that the pleasures they have obtained will disappear from them. Whereas Allah's blessings will never run out, no matter how much humans take from them. Allah has also promised those who spend their wealth with a reward that is many times greater than what they spend.

Stinginess is a characteristic and nature of humans to varying degrees. It is this bad character and nature that causes humans to disobey Allah's commands and be reluctant to heed His prohibitions. Allah says:

And you love wealth with exceeding love. (al-Fajr/89: 20)

And indeed, in the love of wealth he is strong. (al-'adiyat/100: 8)
text.101:
This verse explains that Allah SWT gave nine kinds of miracles to Musa (Moses), peace be upon him, as proof of his apostleship, when he was sent to Pharaoh and his people. Nevertheless, Pharaoh and his people still refused the call of Prophet Musa to believe in Allah, the Creator. In another verse, it is explained how Pharaoh and his people denied Musa's call.

Allah SWT says:

"And they rejected them, while in their hearts they were convinced of them, out of injustice and arrogance. Then see how was the end of the corrupters." (an-Naml/27: 14)

The commentators of the Quran (mufasir) differ in opinion regarding the meaning of the nine signs mentioned above. According to Ibn Abbas, as narrated by 'Abd Razzaq, Sa'id bin Manshur, Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari, and Ibn Mundzir, the nine signs are the staff, the hand, the flood, the locusts, the lice, the frogs, the blood, the years of drought, and the shortage of fruits. This opinion is agreed upon by the majority of scholars (jumhur ulama).

Other commentators, such as ar-Razi, are of the opinion that the nine signs mentioned above are various prohibitions. He bases his opinion on a hadith of the Prophet Muhammad SAW narrated by Ahmad, at-Tirmidzi, al-Baihaqi, Ath-thabrani, an-Nasa'i, and Ibn Majah from Shafwan bin Asal al-Muradi, when he was asked by a Jew, that the nine signs here are nine kinds of prohibitions, namely: do not associate partners with Allah, do not kill a soul except with right, do not commit adultery, do not steal, do not practice magic, do not consume riba (interest), do not slander an innocent person to the ruler, do not accuse virtuous women of adultery, and do not violate the rules on the Sabbath. Ibn Shihab Al-Khafaji said, "This is the tafsir (interpretation) that is followed in interpreting this verse."

Allah commands Prophet Muhammad SAW to ask about the story of Musa to the Jews who lived in his time, such as Abdullah bin Salam and others, and they would surely confirm it. Their acknowledgement of the truth of Prophet Musa's message would increase his faith and conviction. It also aims to ensure that the Prophet SAW is certain that the story is also found in their book.

Ask the Jews, and they will surely explain that Musa (Moses), peace be upon him, came to Pharaoh bringing the religion of monotheism and presenting various miracles. However, Pharaoh denied it, even saying that Musa was a person of unsound mind, who claimed to be a messenger of Allah.
text.102: Moses said to Pharaoh that indeed Pharaoh already knew that the One who sent down these signs (ayat) was the Lord who possesses the heavens and the earth. This was explained by Prophet Moses as proof and clarification that what he was calling to was the truth. Only those with pure hearts can accept this call. Furthermore, Prophet Moses said to Pharaoh that his heart was impure and he had no willingness to accept the call. Whatever truth was presented to him would still not make him accept the call.
text.103: After Pharaoh saw Moses' persistence in conveying his message, and that it would endanger himself and his power, Pharaoh planned to expel Moses and his followers from the land of Egypt, either by banishing them or eliminating them. However, Allah SWT first drowned Pharaoh and his followers in the sea of Qulzum.
text.104: Then Allah SWT saved Musa (Moses) and the Children of Israel and commanded them to inhabit the land that had been promised to them until the appointed time. When that time arrives, they will be caused to die and then resurrected on the Day of Judgment, to establish the most just decision among them. At that time, they and their enemies will be mixed and united to receive recompense from Allah. Good deeds will be rewarded with manifold rewards, while evil deeds will be recompensed with the punishment of Hellfire.
text.105:
In this verse, Allah SWT affirms to the Messenger SAW that Allah has indeed revealed the Qur'an from His side. Therefore, people should not doubt it or turn away from it.

In another verse, Allah SWT says:

"But Allah bears witness to that which He has sent down to you (O Muhammad). He has sent it down with His knowledge, and the angels bear witness. And sufficient is Allah as Witness." (an-Nisa'/4: 166)

The Qur'an carries various true teachings that bring order and prosperity to mankind. Within it are teachings about morality, divine creed, regulations, laws, history, and science. All its contents are always preserved, both its words and meanings will not be tainted by additions or subtractions that cause chaos and confusion, as Allah explained in His word:

"Indeed, it is We who sent down the Qur'an and indeed, We will be its guardian." (al-Hijr/15: 9)

His word again:

"(Falsehood cannot approach it from before or from behind (in the past or in the future); [it is] sent down from a [Lord who is] Wise and Praiseworthy." (Fushshilat/41: 42)

Thus, Allah explains the characteristics of the Qur'an with all guarantees of its purity from the hands of humans who try to defile it. It was revealed to the Prophet Muhammad SAW who was sent to mankind to give good news about rewards and paradise for those who believe and are obedient to the teachings of religion, and to give warnings about torment and hell for those who disbelieve and commit sins.
text.106:
In this verse, Allah swt explains that the Qur'an was revealed to the Prophet Muhammad saw gradually, part by part, so that he could recite it to his people and provide understanding slowly. The first verses of the Qur'an were revealed in the month of Ramadan, on the night of Qadar, and then continued to be revealed to the Prophet gradually according to needs and events that occurred over a period of less than twenty-three years. With this gradual revelation, Muslims gained great advantages and benefits, including:

First: It was easy for Muslims to memorize it when it was revealed.

Second: Muslims had the opportunity to understand each group of verses that were revealed, because the broad scope of its meaning required sufficient time to understand it in order to gain accurate and correct understanding.

Third: Muslims did not experience significant psychological shock in facing the various changes brought about by Islam. Before the arrival of Islam, they adhered to various animistic beliefs and did not have regulations and ways of life that were obeyed. The gradual revelation of the Qur'an made it easier for them to adapt to the new teachings, both those related to *aqidah* (creed) and those related to worship and society.

Fourth: Some verses of the Qur'an are explanations related to an event that occurred.

Allah swt says:

And they (the disbelievers) do not come to you with an argument except that We bring you the truth and the best explanation. (al-Furqan/25: 33)

Thus, Muslims felt that they always received guidance and direction from Allah swt when facing every event that occurred among them.

For the Prophet Muhammad saw, the gradual revelation of the Qur'an was of great benefit in strengthening his heart, as Allah explained in His word:

And those who disbelieve say, "Why was the Qur'an not revealed to him all at once?" Thus [it was] that We may strengthen your heart thereby. And We have spaced it distinctly. (al-Furqan/25: 32)

Generally, the verses that were revealed ranged from five to ten verses according to need, as Umar bin Khaththab said:

Narrated from Umar r.a., he said, "Learn the Qur'an five verses at a time. Because indeed Jibril revealed it five verses at a time." (Riwayat al-Baihaqi).
text.107:
In this verse, Allah swt commands His Messenger to state firmly to the polytheists who deny the truth of the Qur'an that if they were to believe, their faith would not enrich the treasures of His mercy. Likewise, if they remain in denial, refusing to believe in the Qur'an, their denial and rejection would not diminish the greatness of Allah swt. Allah says:

"And they say, 'We will not believe you until you break open for us from the ground a spring.'" (al-Isra'/17: 90)

This statement of the Messenger saw is a rebuke and condemnation of the polytheists, and contains contempt for them. Whatever their attitude towards the Qur'an, it is not worthy of attention. The truth of the Qur'an does not depend on the attitude of those who deny it. It is not surprising that they reject the truth of the Qur'an, because they are indeed people of Jahiliyyah (ignorance). But the good and educated people among them will certainly believe and submit completely when they hear the verses of the Qur'an recited. Like Zaid bin Amru bin Nufail and Waraqah bin Naufal who had read the previous holy books before the Qur'an was revealed, and they knew that in time a prophet of the end times would be born. They prostrated and gave thanks to Allah swt who had fulfilled His promise, namely sending Muhammad saw as the last messenger. With the revelation of this verse, the Prophet Muhammad saw felt comforted, because the faith of the educated is more meaningful than the faith of the ignorant, even though the faith of the ignorant is still hoped for.
text.108:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains that those who have been given knowledge utter tasbih, which is the phrase Subhanallah (Glory be to Allah), when prostrating in gratitude to Allah SWT. They purify God from attributes that are not befitting of Him, such as breaking His promise to mankind to send a messenger. They also say that indeed Allah's promise has come and become a reality.

This verse shows the virtue of reciting tasbih in prostration. 'Aisha r.a. said, "The Messenger SAW often recited in his prostration and bowing:

"Mahasuci Engkau ya Allah Tuhan kami, kami bertasbih dengan memuji-Mu. Ya Allah ampunilah aku." (Glory be to You, O Allah, our Lord, we glorify You with praise. O Allah, forgive me.) (Narrated by Muslim in his Sahih)
text.109:
Then Allah swt added in this verse praiseworthy qualities to those who have been given knowledge. They fall upon their faces, prostrating to Allah while weeping due to various feelings that strike their hearts, such as feelings of fear of Allah, and feelings of gratitude for the birth of the promised messenger. The influence of the teachings of the Qur'an permeates their souls when they hear the verses being recited, and increases their humility and submissiveness. Thus, they feel how small humans are in the sight of Allah swt. Such are the characteristics of knowledgeable people who have reached a noble rank. Their hearts become submissive and their eyes shed tears when the Qur'an is recited to them. Shedding tears when hearing or reading the Qur'an is highly commendable in the view of Islam.

The Messenger of Allah saw said:

Read the Qur'an and weep, and if you cannot weep, then strive as hard as you can to weep. (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi from Sa'ad bin Abi Waqash)

The Messenger of Allah saw also said:

Two eyes that will not be touched by the fire of Hell are the eye that weeps out of fear of Allah swt, and the eye that stays awake at night in the path of Allah (jihad). (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi from Ibn 'Abbas)

A person who weeps out of fear of Allah will not enter Hell, unless cow's milk can return to its udder, and the dust of fighting in the path of Allah and the smoke of the fire of Hell will not gather upon a servant. (Narrated by Muslim and an-Nasa'i from Abu Hurairah)
text.110:
The *sabab nuzul* (reason for revelation) of this verse, according to the narration of Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari from Ibn 'Abbas, is that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) one day prayed in Mecca, and he made a supplication. In his supplication, he uttered the words, "Ya Allah Ya Rahman." The polytheists who heard the Prophet's words said, "Look at the one who has abandoned his religion, he forbids us from praying to two gods, while he himself prays to two gods." Then this verse was revealed.

According to the narration of Adh-ahhak, the reason for the revelation of this verse is that the Jews asked the Messenger why he mentioned the word ar-Rahman so little, even though in the Torah, Allah mentions it a lot." Then this verse was revealed.

If the background to the revelation of this verse is according to the first narration, then Allah explains to the polytheists that the two words (Allah and ar-Rahman), although different, both express the One and Only Essence, the one and only God who is worshipped. This understanding is in accordance with the explanation in verse 111.

If the background to the revelation of this verse is the second narration, then Allah explains to the Jews that both words are good to use to express what is intended. The Jews considered the word ar-Rahman to be better, because that is the attribute that Allah likes the most, so it is often mentioned in the Torah. Ar-Rahman is mentioned a lot in the Torah because the Prophet Musa (Moses), peace be upon him, had a harsh and angry nature. Therefore, Allah often mentioned the words ar-Rahman so that he would interact with his people with love and affection, and as a prophet, he would certainly emulate the attributes of Allah.

In this verse, Allah Almighty explains about the oneness of His Essence with good names. These good names only describe His attributes of perfection, not the existence of Allah standing alone as the polytheists assume.

After stating the similarity of the two words, Allah affirms in this verse that both words are good to use for prayer, because God has *al-asma'ul husna* (the most beautiful names). God provides information with *al-husna* (the most beautiful) for His names, because it contains an understanding that encompasses all the attributes of perfection, glory, and beauty that no creature resembles.

The Jews do not actually deny Allah's good names. It's just that they consider ar-Rahman to be the best name among God's other names. This is what is not justified in this verse because both names are included in *al-asma'ul husna*. The same opinion is also held by Muslims, where according to them, there is a higher name among *al-asma'ul husna*. It is narrated that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) heard a man reciting a prayer:

"Ya Allah, indeed I ask You, so that I truly testify that You are Allah, there is no god but You, the One and the place where all creatures depend. Who was not born and was not begotten and there is no one equal to Him." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi from Abdullah bin Buraidah al-Aslami from his father)

After hearing the prayer, the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"By Allah, in Whose hand is my soul, truly that man prayed with the Great Name of God (*al-asma' al-A'dham*), that if Allah is called with (mentioning) that name, He will surely perfect it, and if Allah is asked with (mentioning) that name, He will surely give." (Narrated by Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari from Sa'ad)

It is also narrated by Muslim, Ahmad, at-Tirmidhi, and Ibn Abi Hatim from Asma' binti Yazid that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"The Most Great Name of Allah Ta'ala is in these two verses, namely:

And your God is One God, there is no god but He, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. (al-Baqarah/2: 163)

And the second verse is in the opening of Surah ali 'Imran:

Alif Lam Mim. Allah, there is no god but He. The Ever-Living, the Sustainer of [all] existence. (ali 'Imran/3: 1-2)

Then at the end of this verse, Allah commands the Messenger that when praying, do not read the verses in a loud voice and not in a low voice either, but in between the two. What is meant by reading this verse includes reading the basmalah and other verses. If the Messenger read in a loud voice, of course the polytheists would hear it and they would then mock, criticize, and insult the Qur'an, the Prophet, and his companions. But do not read in a voice that is too low so that the companions cannot hear it clearly. This prohibition was revealed when the Messenger was still in Mecca based on the narration of Ibn 'Abbas.

According to the narration of Ibn 'Abbas, when the Messenger was in Mecca, he was told to read the verses in a voice that was not too loud, but also not too low, it was forbidden to read in a soft and low voice so that it could not be heard. But after migrating to Medina, the issue was no longer discussed except that reading verses in prayer in a voice that was excessively loud was still not justified.
text.111:
In this verse, the Prophet is taught how to praise Allah swt, who possesses the attributes of oneness, perfection, and majesty. Therefore, only Allah is entitled to receive all kinds of praise and gratitude from His servants and creatures for all the blessings bestowed upon them.

This verse explains three attributes of Allah swt:

First: That indeed Allah does not have a son, because whoever has a son certainly does not enjoy all the blessings he possesses, but some of those blessings are prepared for his son whom he leaves behind when he dies. Allah swt is exalted above such attributes. A person who has a child is prevented from enjoying all his rights in all circumstances. Therefore, humans are not worthy of receiving praise from all creatures. With this verse, Allah swt explains and refutes the views of the Jews who say 'Uzair is the son of God, also the opinion of the Christians who say that Al-Masih is the son of God, or the assumption of the polytheists that the angels are the daughters of God.

Second: That indeed Allah swt has no partner in His kingdom. If He had a partner, it would certainly be difficult to determine which of the two is entitled to receive praise, gratitude, and devotion from creatures. One of the two gods would certainly need help from the other, and ultimately neither god would stand alone and be absolutely sovereign over this universe.

Third: That indeed no one among the lowly is given power by Allah that will protect him from enemies who threaten him.

Thus, Allah swt is free from all attributes that diminish His perfection, so that His servants do not hesitate to offer prayers, gratitude, and praise to Him. Then the Prophet saw was commanded to glorify Him, both in word and in deed. Glorifying and sanctifying Allah is as follows:

First: Glorifying Allah swt in His Essence by believing that Allah's existence is obligatory because of His Essence itself and does not need anything else. He does not need anything from this existence.

Second: Glorifying Allah swt in His attributes, by believing that He alone possesses all the attributes of perfection and is far from the attributes of deficiency.

Third: Glorifying Allah swt in His *af'al* (actions) by believing that nothing happens in this universe except in accordance with His wisdom and will.

Fourth: Glorifying Allah swt in His laws, by believing that He alone is the Ruler who is obeyed in this universe, where commands and prohibitions originate from Him. No one can limit or invalidate His provisions over anything. He is the One who honors and He is also the One who humiliates those whom He wills.

Fifth: Glorifying His names, namely calling upon and mentioning Allah with good names (*al-asma'ul husna*). Not attributing to God except with attributes of holiness and perfection.
